Play details
If you know not me, you know no bodie, part ii. Genre: History. Date first published: 1605. Date first performed: 1604-1605.

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by IDREF which point to the following.

div2.stage: Enter one of Greshams Factors and a Barbary Marchant.

sp.speaker: Factor.
sp.p:
My Master sir, requests your company,
About confirming certain covenants
Touching your last nights conference.

sp.speaker: Marchant.
sp.p:
The Sugars.
Believe me, to his credit be it spoke,
He is a man of heedful providence,
And one that by innative courtesy
Wins love from Strangers, be it without offence,
How are his present fortunes reckoned?

sp.speaker: Fact.
sp.p:
Neither to flatter nor detract from him,
He is a Merchant of good estimate,
Care how to get, and fore-cast to increase,
(If so they be accounted) be his faults.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
They are especial virtues, being clear
From avarice and base extortion.
But here he comes: Good day, to Master. Gresham,
You keep your word.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
Else should I ill deserve
The title that I wear, a Merchant's tongue
Should not strike false.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
What think you of my proffer,
Touching the Sugar?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
I bethought myself
Both of the gain and losses incident,
And this I take it was the whole circumstance:
It was my motion and I think your promise,
To get me a sealed Patent from your king
For all your Barbary Sugar at a price,
During the kings life; and for his princely love,
I am to send him threescore thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.p:
It was so conditioned, and to that effect
His highness promise is already past,
And if you dare give credit to my trust,
Send but your private letters to your Factor,
That deals for your affairs in Barbary,
His Majesty shall either seal your Patent,
Or I will return the money to your Factor.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
As much as I desire; pray sir draw near
And taste a cup of wine, whilst I consider
And thoroughly scan such accidental doubts,
As may concern a matter of such moment.

sp.speaker: Mar:
sp.p: At your best leisure.

sp.speaker: Gresh:
sp.p:
I will resolve you straight,
Bethink thee Gresham, threescore thousand pounds
A good round sum: let not the hope of gain
Draw thee to loss. I am to have a Patent
For all the Barbary Sugars at a rate,
The gain clears half in half, but then the hazard.
My term continues during the kings life,
The King may die before my first return,
Then where is my Cash? why, so the King may live
These 40. years, then where is Greshams gain:
It stands in this as in all ventures else
Doubtful, no more, I will through what ever it cost.
So much clear gain, or so much coin clear lost.
Within there ho.

sp.speaker: Fact:
sp.p: At hand sir, did you call?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
How thrives our Cash? what is it well increased?
I speak like one that must be forced to borrow.

sp.speaker: 1. Fact.
sp.p: Your worships merry.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
Merry, tell me knave,
Dost not thou think that three score thousand pounds,
Would make an honest Merchant try his friends?

sp.speaker: Fact.
sp.p:
Yes, by my faith sir, but you have a friend
Would not see you stand out for twice the sum.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
Praise God for all, but what is the common rumour
Touching my bargain with the King of Barbary?

sp.speaker: 1. Fact.
sp.p:
It is held your credit, and your Countries honour,
That being but a Merchant of the City,
And taken in a manner unprovided,
You should upon a mere presumption
And naked promise, part with so much Cash,
Which the best Merchants both in Spain and France,
Denied to venture on.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
Good: but withal,
what do they think in general of the Bargain?

sp.speaker: 1. Fact.
sp.p:
That if the King confirm and seal your Patent,
London will yield you partners enough.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
I think no less: Go fit you for the sea,
I mean to send you into Barbary.
You unto Venice, You to Portugal,
Provide you presently: where much is spent,
Some must be got, thrift should be provident:
Come hither Cousin, all the rest depart.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
I had as good depart too, for he will ring a peal in mine care,
It willsound worse than a passing bell.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
I have taken note of your bad husbandry,
Careless respect, and prodigal expense,
And out of my experience counsel you.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
And I hope good Uncle, you think, I am as ready to
take good counsel, as you to give it, and I doubt not, but to clear,
myself of all objections that foul mouthed envy shall intimate
against me.

sp.speaker: Gres.
sp.p:
How can you satisfy the great complaint
Preferred against you by old Mistress Blunt.
A woman of approved honesty.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
That is true, her honesty hath been proved oftener
than once or twice: but do you know her Uncle? are you inward
with her course of life, she is a common midwife for trade-fallen
virginity, there are more maidenheads charged and discharged
in her house in a year, than pieces at the Artillery
yard.

sp.speaker: Gres.
sp.p: She bring sin further proof, that you miscalled her.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
I never called her out of name, by this hand Uncle, to
my remembrance:

sp.speaker: Gres.
sp.p: No: she says you called her Bawd.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
True; and I have known her answer to it a thousand
times; tut Uncle it is here name, and I know who gave it her too,
by the same token her Godfather gave her a bowed angel standing
at the door which she hath kept time out a mind.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p: Antonio reports you love his wife.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Love, why alas, Uncle, I hold it parcel of my duty to
love my neighbours, and should I hate his wife, no man would
hold me a fit member for a common wealth.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p: He hates you for it.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Why, alas Uncle, that is not my fault, I will love him nevertheless,
you know we are commanded to love our enemies, and
though he would see me hanged, yet will I love his wife.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p: He told me, you bestowed a gown of a strumpet.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Why, alas Uncle, the poor whore went naked, and
you know the text commands us to clothe the naked, and
deeds of mercy be imputed to us for faults, God help the elect.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
Well, if your prodigal expenses be aimed
At any virtuous and religious end,
It is the more tolerable, and I am proud
You can so probably excuse yourself.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Well Uncle to approve my words, as indeed good
words without deeds are like your green fig-tree without fruit.
I have sworn myself to a more conformable and strict course
of life.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p: Well Cousin, hoping you will prove a new man.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
A new man, what else Uncle, I will be a new man from
the top to toe, or I will want of my will: Instead of Tennis-Court,
my morning Exercise shall be at Saint Antlms: I will leave Ordinaries,
and to the end I may forswear Dicing and Drabbing,
keep me more short Uncle, only allow me good apparel, good
Rags I will stand to it are better than seven years' prenticeship,
for they will make a man free of any, nay of all Companies without
Indenture, Fathers copy, or any help whatsoever, but I see
my error, wild Youth must be bridled, keep me short good
Uncle.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
On these presumptions I will apparel thee,
And to confirm this resolution,
I will prefer you unto Master Hobson,
A man of a well known discretion.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Anything good Uncle, I have served my prenticeship already,
but bind me again and I shall be content, and it is but
reason neither, send me to the Conduit with the water-tankard,
I will beat Linen, Bucks, or anything to redeem my negligence.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
Your education challenge more respect.
The Factor dealt for him in France, is dead.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: And you intend to send me in his room,

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p: I do indeed.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Aye it is well done Uncle, and it will not be amiss in policy
to do so: the only way to curb a dissolute youth as I am,
is to send him from his acquaintance, and therefore send me
far enough good Uncle, send me into France and spare not,
and if that reclaim me not, give me over as one past all goodness.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
Now afore God my thoughts were much against him,
And my intent was to have chid him roundly,
But his submissive recantation.
Hath made me friends with him, Come follow me,
I will do thee good, and that immediately.

sp.speaker: Iohn:
sp.p:
Thank you good Uncle, you will send me into France,
all Forboone: and I do not show you the right trick of a Cousin
afore I leave England, I will give you leave to call me Cut, and cozen
me of my patrimony as you have done.

div2.stage: Enter Hobsons prentises and a boy.

sp.speaker: 1. Prent.
sp.p:
Prithee fellow Goodman, set forth the ware, and
look to the shop a little, I will but drink a cup of wine with a
Customer at the Rose and Crown in the Poultry, and come
again presently.

sp.speaker: 2. Pren.
sp.p:
Foot I cannot, I must needs step to the Dagger in
Cheap to send a Letter into the Country unto my father, stand
by, you are the youngest prentice, look you to the shop.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Where be these varlets, bones'a'me, at Tavern?
Knaues, villains, spend goods, foot my Customers
Must either serve themselves, or pack unserved.
Now they peep like Italian pantaloons
Behind an Arras, but I will start you knaues,
I have a shoeing horn to draw on your liquor,
What say you to a piece of a salt Eel?
Come forth you hang dogs, bones'a'me the knaues
Fleer in my face, they know me too well,
I talk and prate, and lay it not on their jacks,
And the proud jacks care not a fig for me:
But bones'a'me, I will turn another leaf.
Where have you been sir?

sp.speaker: 1. Pren.
sp.p:
An honest Customer
Requested me, to drink a pint of wine.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Bones'a'me, must your crimson throat
Be scoured with wine? your master is glad of beer:
But you will die bankrupts, knaues, and bankrupts all,
And where have you been?

sp.speaker: 2. Pren.
sp.p: At breakfast with a Dagger pie sir.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
A Dagger Pie! ud's daggers death, these knaues
Set cock-a-hoop, but Hobson pays for all.
But bones'a'me, knaues either mend your manners.
Leave Alehouses, taverns, and the tippling mates,
Your Punks, and cockatrices, or I will clap ye
Close up in Bridewell, bones of me I will do it,

sp.speaker: 2. Pren.
sp.p: Beseech you sir, pardon this first offence.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
First, bones a God, why it is your common course,
And you must needs be guzzling, go by turns,
One to the Alehouse, and two keep the shop.

sp.speaker: 2. Pren.
sp.p: It shall be done sir, how much ware would you have?

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p:
Five pounds worth in such Commodities,
as I bespoke last night.

sp.speaker: 1. Pren.
sp.p: They are ready sorted.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p: God bless you Master. Hobson.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Bones are god, knave, thou art welcome what is the news
At bawdy Barnewell, and at Sturbridge Fair?
What, have your London wenches any trading?

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p:
After the old sort sir, they visit the Tollbooth, and the empties
Bullring still.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Good girls, they do their kind, what your packs
Good news, a sign you bring your purses full,
And bones'a'God, full purses must be welcome:
Sort out their wares: welcome is your due:
Pay the old debt, and pen and ink for new.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p: We have for you sir, as white as Bears' teeth.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Bones'a'God, knaues you are welcome, but what news?
What news in the Country? what Commodities
Are most respected with your country Girls?

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p:
Faith sir, our Country girls are a kin to your London
Courtiers, every month sick of a new fashion, the horning busk
and silken bridelaces are in good request with the Parsons wife,
your huge poking stick, and french periwig, with Chambermaids,
and waiting-gentlewomen, now your Puritans poker is
not so huge, but somewhat longer, a long slender poking stick
is the all in all with your Suffolk Puritan, your silkband, half
farthingales, and chargeable Fore-parts are common, not a
wench of thirteen but wears a changeable forepart.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
An ancient wearing: there is some changeable stuff
Has been a wear with women, time out of mind,

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p:
Besides sir, many of our young married men, have taken
an order to wear yellow Garters, Points, and Shootings, and it is
thought, yellow will grow a custom.

sp.speaker: Hob:
sp.p: It has been used long at London.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p:
And it is thought it willcome in request in the Country
too, it is a fashion, that three or four young wenches have promised
me their husbands shall wear, or they will miss of their
marks: then your mask, silk-lace, washed Gloves, carnation
New-castle, you shall not have a Kitchen-maid scrape trenchers
without her washed Gloves, a Dairy wench will not ride to market
to sell her Buttermilk, without her mask and her busk.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Still a good hearing, let the country pay
Well for their pride, it is gratis here at London,
And that is the cause it is grown so general:
But feed their humours, and do not spare,
Bring Country money for our London ware.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p: Where is Master. Hobson, cry you mercy sir.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
No harm good Master. Gresham, pray draw near
I will but dispatch a few old Customers,
And bend a present ear to your discourse.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p: At your best leisure.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Nay my task is done:
O Master. Gresham it was a golden world
When we were Boys, an honest Country-yeoman,
Such as our fathers were, God rest their souls
Would wear white Kersey: bones'a'me you knaues,
Stools for these Gentlemen, your worships welcome.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p: You know my business.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
About your kinsman,
He shall be welcome: beseech you Gentlemen
Less of your courtesy: when shall we see the Youth?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p: Why this is he.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Which, bones'a'me man, which?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p: Why this.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Which, where, what this young gentleman!
Bones'a'me man, he is not for Hobsons turn.
He looks more like my Master than my servant.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
I must confess he is a Gentleman,
And my near kinsman: were he mine own child,
His service should be yours.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
I thank you for it,
And for your sake I will give him entertainment
But Gentleman if you become my man,
You must become more civil: bones'a'me,
What a curled pate is here? I must have it off,
You see my Livery, Hobsons men are known
By their Frieze Coats: if you will dwell with me,
You must be plain, and leave of bravery.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
I hope sir to put on such civil conformity, as you shall
not repent my entertainment.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Pray God it prove so.

sp.speaker: Gresh:
sp.p:
If he do respect
an Uncle's love, let him be diligent.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Well, Master. Gresham, partly for your love,
And chiefly to supply my present want,
Because you say your kinsman is well seen
Both in languages and factorship,
I do intend to send him into France,
In trust both with my Merchandises and my Cash.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
And if I take not order to cashier that and myself
too, a pox of all French-farthingales.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p: How stand you minded to your Masters motion?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Somewhat unwilling to leave my acquaintance, but
good Uncle, I know you send me out of love, and I hope it will
be a means to call me home the sooner.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p: Pray God it may.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
I will want of my will else, I will play a Merchant's part with
you, I will take up french Commodities, velvet kittles, and taffery
fore-parts; I will have that I go for, or I will make half the hot-houses
in Deep: smoke for this trick.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: What are your books made even with your accounts?

sp.speaker: 1 Pren.
sp.p:
I have compared our wares with our receipt,
And find sir, ten pounds' difference.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Bones'a'me knave,
Ten pounds in a morning: here is the fruit
Of Dagger Pies, and Alehouse guzzlings:
Make even your Reckonings, or Gods mother knaues,
You shall all smart for it.

Hark you fellow Goodman,
Who took the ten pound of the country Chapman
That told my master the new fashions?
Fore God not I.
Not I.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Bones'a'me, knaues,
I have paid soundly for my Country news.
What was his name?
Now afore God, I know not.
I never saw him in the shop till now.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Now bones'a'me, what careless Knaues keep I,
Give me the book, what habit did he wear?
As I remember me, a tawny coat.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Art sure: then set him down Iohn Tawnie-coate.
Ten pound in trust unto Iohn Tawnie-coate.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Bones a God man, these knaues will beggar me.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
Byrlady sir, ten pounds is too much to lose,
But ten times ten pound cannot shake your credit.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Thank God for all: when I came first to town,
It would have shook me shrewdly: but Master. Gresham,
How stands your difference with Sir Thomas Ramsey?
Are you made friends yet?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
He is so obstinate,
That neither Juries, nor Commissions,
Nor the entreaties of his nearest friends,
Can stoop him unto composition.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
It is passing strange: were Hobson in your coat,
Ere I would consume a penny amongst Lawyers,
I would give it poor people, bones'a'me I would.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
A good resolve: but sir Thomas Ramsies mind
Is of another temper, and ere Gresham
Will give away a tittle of his right,
The Law shall beggar me.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Bones'a'me, man, it will do that quickly.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
To prevent which course,
The Lady Ramsey hath by earnest suit,
Procured the reverent Preacher Doctor Nowell,
A man well reckoned for his grave respect.
To compromise and end our difference,
The place the Lombard, ten of clock the hour
Appointed for the hearing of our cause.
Shall I request your friendly company,

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
With all my heart, both company and purse:
Bones'a'me, knaues, look better to my shop:
Men of our trade must wear good husbands eyes,
Amongst many Chap-men there are few that buys.
My leisure now your business attends,
Time is won not lost, that is spent to make men friends.

div2.stage: Enter Doctor Nowell, and my Lady Ramsie.

sp.speaker: Ladie.
sp.p:
Good Master Doctor Nowell, let your love
Now show itself unto me: such as they,
Men of the chiefest note within this City
To be at such a jar, doth make me blush
Whom it doth scarce concern: you are a good man,
Take you the course in hand and make them friends,
It will be a good day's work, if so it end.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.p:
My Lady Ramsie, I have heard ere this
Of their contentions, their long suit in Law,
How by good friends they have been persuaded both,
Yet both but deaf to fair persuasion
What good will my word do with headstrong men?
Breath blown against the wind, retires again:

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Although to Gentlemen and Citizens,
They have been so rash, yet to so grave a man,
Of whom none speak but speak with reverence,
Whose words are gathered in by every ear
As flowers receive the dew that comfort them,
They will be more attentive: pray take it in hand,
It is a good deed, it willwith your virtue stand.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.p:
To be a make-peace doth become me well,
The charitable motion good in you,
And in good sooth it willmake me wet mine eyes,
To see them even, have been so long at odds.
And by my means, I will do the best I can,
But God must bless my words, for mass but man.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
I thank you heartily, and by the hour I know.
They will be presently here on the Lombard,
Whither I drew you for this intent:
And see, sir Thomas is come: pray break with him.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.p: Good day to sir Thomas Ramsie.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p:
Master. Dean of Paul's, as much to you:
It is strange to see you here in Lumberstreet,
This place of traffic whereon Merchants meet.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.p: It is not my custom: but sir Thomas.

div2.stage: Enter M. Gresham, and old Hobson.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Come, come
Now body'a'me, I swear not every day,
You are too too much to blame: two Citizens,
Such as yourself, and sir Thomas Ramsie are,
To beat yourselves in Law six or seven year,
Make Lawyers, Attorneys' clerks, and knaues, to spend
Your money in a brabbling controversy,
Even like two fools: see where the other is,
With our Dean of Paul's, never better met,
We two as Umpires will conclude a strife
Before the Clock strike twelve, that now is eleven:
Lawyers this full seven year have brabbled in,
And with a cup or two of merry-go-down,
Make them shake hands: Is it not well said Master. Dean?

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.p: And I could wish it as well done, Master. Hobson.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
I will have you both know though you are my friends,
I scorn my cause should stoop or yield to him,
Although he be reputed Ramsie the rich.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p:
And Gresham shall perceive that Ramsies purse,
Shall make him spend the wealth of Osterley,
But he shall know.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p: Know, what shall I know?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: That Ramsie is as good a man as Gresham.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p: And Gresham is as good a man as Ramsie.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Tut, tut, tut.

sp.speaker: Gresh
sp.p: Tut in thy teeth although thou art a Knight.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Bones'a'me, you are both to blame:
We two like friends, come to conclude your strife,
And you like fishwives fall a scolding here.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.p: How stands the difference betwixt you my good friends?

sp.speaker: Ladie.
sp.p:
The impatience both of the one and other,
Will not permit to hear each other speak:
I will tell the cause for both, and thus it is,
There is a Lordship called Osterley,
That Master. Gresham hath both bought and built upon.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p: And it is a goodly Manor, Master. Dean.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Which Osterley before he dealt therein,
Sir Thomas my husband here did think to buy,
And had given earnest for it.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p:
Then Gresham here, deals with the Land-seller,
And buys my bargain most dishonestly.

sp.speaker: Gres.
sp.p:
God for his mercy touch mine honesty,
Away with compromise, with taking up,
The Law shall try my cause and honesty.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: It willprove no better than it should Gresham.

sp.speaker: Gres.
sp.p: It willprove as good as Ramsies, Ramsie.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Do not I know thy rising?

sp.speaker: Gres.
sp.p: Aye, and I know thine

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Why mine was honestly.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p: And so was mine.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Heyday, bones'a'me
Was it ever seen two men to scold before?
Here is, I know thy rising, and I know thine,
When as Gods blessing, that hath raised them both,
Am I worse because in Edwards days,
When Popery went down, I did engross
Most of the Beads that were within the Kingdom,
That when Queen Marie, had renewed that Church,
They that would pray on Beads were forced to me:
I made them stretch their purse-strings, grew rich thereby,
Beads were to me a good commodity.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p: No matter for your beads, my right is my right.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Yet Gresham shall well know he hath done me wrong.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p: There is law enough to right you, take your course.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.p:
Reason being made man's guide, why is it that force
Are violent passions to sweep the soul
Into such head-long mischiefs: it is only this,
Reason would rule, Nature a Rebel is.
You know the fire of your contention,
Hath only cherishing and is maintained
From vild affections, whose strength is but thus
As sultry heat doth make us shun the fire,
An extreme cold doth alter that desire:
All things that have beginnings, have their ends.
Your hate must have conclusion, then be friends.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Friends, Master. Doctor Nowell, look you here,
Here is Master. Greshams hand.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I will bring the tother.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
This seven year they have been in law together.
How much such men as they in seven years spend,
Lawyers may laugh at, but let wise men judge.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p: Friend Hobson.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Wife Lady.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Bones'a'me, I will hold you fast,
I will not have a couple of such men
Make cackling lawyers rich, and themselves fools,
And for a trifling cause: as I am old Hobson.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p: Sir Thomas Ramsie.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Master Gresham.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Body of me, both shall be schooled, Master. D. Nowell,
You know the cause that this contention,
Is only that he bought a piece of land
This had given earnest for, all Adams earth,
And Adams earth is free for Adams sons,
And it is a shame men should contend for it:
What ere you speak shall for a sentence stand,
And being spoke, they shall shake hand in hand.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.p:
If I must then decide the difference,
Thus it shall be: because that Sir Thomas Ramsie,
Had earnest given before you bought the Land,
Though you were not acquainted with so much,
I do award he have a hundred pound
Toward his charges, and for that you
have both paid for the Land, and built upon it,
It shall continue yours: the money you have spent,
Either account it lost, or badly lent.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p: Gods precious, I have spent five hundred pound,

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: And so have I,

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
No matter.
The judgment stands, only this verdict too,
Had you before the law foreseen the loss,
You had not now come home by weeping cross:
Strifes may as well have end betwixt honest men,
Lawyers set fools to Law, then laugh at them.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
Fore God it is true: and now I think upon it,
We might at first have ended it by friends,
And made ourselves merry with the money:
But being done, it is done, then sir Thomas Ramsey,
Let us leave both losers, it is but a thousand pound,
And if you be as well content as I,
Here we will shake hands and let our anger dye.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Shake hands, by the Marie god, sir Thomas what else,

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p:
You show yourselves our friends, to make us friends,
Then in good sooth I will not be obstinate.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Nay, Master. Doctor Nowell join their hands,
I know the reverent regard of you
Hath tempered both their hearts.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
Madam, it is true: I think to any but so good a man,
We should have both been headstrong: but come.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.p:
With all my heart, long may you live together,
As friend should be to friend, brother to brother.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p: Amen, amen, sir Thomas.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Amen, amen, Master Gresham.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Amen, amen, to you both.
And is not it is better than every Term
to trot after Lawyers?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
Good sooth it is true, if we could think it so,
But it is man's nature, he desires his woe.
Now passion of me sir Thomas, a cruel storm,
And we stay long we shall be wet to the skin,
I do not like it, nay and it angers me
That such a famous City as this is,
Wherein so many gallant Merchants are,
have not a place to meet in, but in this,
Where every shower of rain must trouble them:
I cannot tell but if I live: let us step into the Popes head,
We shall be dropping dry if stay here:
I will have a roof built, and such a roof,
That Merchants and their wives, friend and their friends
Shall walk underneath it as now in Paul's.
What day of the Month is this?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Day Master. Gresham, let me see:
I took a fellow's word for twenty pound
The tenth of March, the tenth of March.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
The tenth of March, well if I live,
I will raise a work shall make our Merchants say,
It was a good shower that fell upon that day. How now Jack?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Sir, my Master. here having preferred me to be his Factor into France,
I am come to take my leave of you.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
I thank him for his care of thee: Master. Hobson,
My kinsman is come to take his leave of me,
He tells me you are sending him for France.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Bones'a'me knave, art there yet?
I thought thou hadst been half way there by this.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: I did but stay sir, to take my leave of my Uncle.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
O Master. Hobson, he comes in a very good time,
I was bethinking me whom I might send
To fetch this hundred pound, I am set to pay
To sir Thomas Ramsey: nay, as we are friends
We will have all Covenants kept before we part.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: God grant that I may see it.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
Here Iohn take this sealed Ring,
Bid Timothy presently send me a hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Aye sir.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
I am sure he hath it ready told for thee,
We will stay here on the Lombard till thou comest.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.p: Nay stay good Iohn, thou knowest my dwelling Iohn?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: In Paul's Church-yard Sir.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.p: The hundred pound thou art sent for, bring it thither.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Yes marry will I sir.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.p:
And my good friends, since that so long a strife
Hath end by my persuasion, I will entreat,
My house may entertain you for this time.
Where with such necessaries we will pass the time,
As God shall best be pleased, and you contented:
I keep no riot, nor you look for none,
Only my table is for everyone.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
A cup of Sack and welcome Master. Dean,
Nature is best contented with a mean.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
As I told you Timothy,
You must send my Uncle straight a hundred pound:
He dines at Doctor Nowels, and gave me in charge
To haste with the money after him.

sp.speaker: Thimo.
sp.p:
You come to me Iohn for a hundred pound, I thank
my spiritual maker I have the charge of many hundreds of his
now Iohn: I hope Iohn you fear God.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Fear God, S'foot what else, I fear God and the devil too.

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.p:
I must tell you Iohn and I know it, you have not fed of
the spiritual food, but edified by faith and suffered the tares of
the wild affections to be burnt.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Foot thou wouldst not have me make myself a French
Martyr, to be burnt at these years wouldst thou?

sp.speaker: Tym.
sp.p:
I have known them Iohn of our Church, have been
burnt for other sins before thy years.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Aye by my faith Timothy it may be you have, for as close as
you carry your teeth together, with indeed good brother, I do
not think but once in a year, a man might find you quartered
betwixt the Mouth at Bishops-gare, and the preaching place in
Spittle.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
Now you talk of the Spittle, I must say in very deed
I have been in the Spittle.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
It is the more like Timothy you have been acquainted
with the pox then.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
But if you should think Iohn, that I would be there to
commit, deal, or to speak more profanely, to venture in the
way of all flesh, you do wrong me being a brother of the faith.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Come right yourself and your Master then, and send
him this one hundred pound, here is his sealed Ring, I hope
a warrant sufficient.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Upon so good security Iohn, I will fit me to deliver it.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Spend it, God send me but once to finger it, and if I
do not make a Flanders reckoning on it, and that is as I have
heard mad wags say, receive it hear and revel it away in an other
place: let me be spit out of the room of good fellowship,
and never have so much favour to touch the skirt of a Taffeta
petticoat.
Tut I am young, mine Uncle is an old chuff,
And I will not want by God, since he hath enough.
I must not let this same wainscot-face, yea and nay, hear me though.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
Here Iohn, accept my duty to my Master, I must tell you
Iohn, I would not have trusted you Iohn, without so sufficient a discharge.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
I am the less beholding unto you, but now I have it, because
you preached to me upon my demand of it, I will be so bold
to lecture to you upon your delivery, Timothie you know the
Proverb good Timothy, That the still Sow eats all the draff;
and no question the most smooth tongued fellow, the more arrant
knave: God forbid I should call you so Timothy, yet I will
leave this for your further remembrance.
Under the yea and nay, men often buy
Much cozenage, find many a lie:
He that with yea and nay makes all his sayings,
Yet proves a Judas in his dealings,
Shall have this written over his grave,
Thy life seemed pure, yet died a knave.

sp.speaker: Timothy.
sp.p:
Do you hear Iohn, you know the Chapmans word
in London, I will trust you but no further than I see you, you have the
hundred pound Iohn, but for that you have wronged us that love
to be edified, I will go with you to my Master, and see the money
delivered.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Why, he trusted me to come with it.

sp.speaker: Timothy.
sp.p:
I care not by yea, and nay, I will go by yea and nay,
I will.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Let me but ask thee this question, Whither dost thou
go, in any love to thy master, or to me?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
Though my master be my master, yet you have stirred
my stomach.

sp.speaker: Iohn:
sp.p:
I thought there was the fruit of your Puritan patience,
come let us along, and if I do not show your religion a trick
shall be scarce digested with pippins or cheese, let me be called
Cut, Come along.

div2.stage: Enter Honestie the Sergeant, and Quick.

sp.speaker: Honestie.
sp.p:
Fellow Quicke, pray thee have a care if thou canst
see Iohn the Upholster, I must needs arrest him.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: How much is the debt?

sp.speaker: Honestie.
sp.p: Some 50. li.

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p: Dost thou think he is able to put in bail to the action?

sp.speaker: Honestie.
sp.p: I think scarce enough.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
Why then we will arrest him to the popes-head, call
for the best cheer in the house, first feed upon him, and then if
he will not come off, carry him to the counter, but if he will stretch
some four or five pounds being the sums so great he shall pass, we will make
him swear he shall not tell he was arrested, and we will swear to
the creditor we cannot meet with him.

sp.speaker: Honest.
sp.p: Fore God thou sayst well.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
I have served Sent the Perfumer, Tallow the Currier,
Quarrell the Glazier, and some three or four more of our poor
smelts so this morning.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Heart I have coursed through two or three Lanes, yet the
miching slave follows me so close I cannot give him the slip
for this hundred pound as God save me now it is in my hand I would
rather be hanged than part from it: Foot, it willmake a man
merry half a year together in France, command wenches or any
thing: part from it quoth you, that were a jest indeed: shall a
young man as I am, and though I say it indifferent proper, go into
a strange country, and not show himself what mettle he is
made of when he comes there: I protest a very good hundred
pound, a hundred pound will go far in France, and when a
man hath it not of his own, who should he make bold withal
for it, if he may not with his Uncle; but see if that thin faced rogue
be not come again, I must have a trick for him.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
For all your fore-long to and fro, by yea and nay, I will
follow you.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Will you, there should be Sergeants hereabouts, will
you: Lord if it be thy will send me to hit of one, and if I do not
show you a trick, thou shouldst be a Sergeant by thy peering so.

sp.speaker: Honest.
sp.p: Why Master. Iohn so I am.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Thou art happily met: I am looking for one, what is thy name?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p:
My name Master. Iohn, I have been merry, at your Uncle's
many a time, my name is Honesty.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Ifaith.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Nay, I will assure you his name is Honesty, and I am Quick his Yeoman.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p:
Honesty! who the pox gave thee that name?
But thou must do an office for my Uncle:
Here Quicke, run thou before and enter the action,
There is money, an action of an hundred pound
Against Timothy Thin-beard, Master. Greshams Factor,
I hope I shall teach you to dog me.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: An action against Thin-beard, I, go.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Here Honesty, there is money for thy arrest,
Be sure to take good Bail or clap him fast:
I hope I shall show you a trick.

sp.speaker: Honest.
sp.p: Mum for that.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
See where he is, God prosper it.
Fasten upon him like a hungry Dog upon a piece of meat:
And if this be not a trick to chaste a fool,
A more knave learn me, and I will go to school.

sp.speaker: Honest.
sp.p: I arrest you Sir.

sp.speaker: Tim:
sp.p: Arrest me, thou servant to Satan: at whose suit?

sp.speaker: Honest.
sp.p: At your Masters, Master. Greshams.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: O God for thy mercy, Master. Iohn, Master. Iohn.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Nay, nay, this 100. li. hath other work in hand for me,
You are in the Devil's hand, and so agree.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: My good friend, now what must become of me?

sp.speaker: Honest.
sp.p:
Unless, we shall to the Tavern, and drink till you
can send for Bail, you must to the Counter.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
Is there no difference made betwixt the faithful and the
unfaithful.

sp.speaker: Honest.
sp.p:
Faith very little in paying of debts: but if you be so
holy, I marvel how you run so far behind hand With your Master.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
I must confess I owe my Master. 500. li. How I came so, it
is not fit to lay the sins of our flesh open to every eye, and you know
the saying, It is bad to do evil, but worse to boast of it: yet he above
knows that sometimes as soon as I have come from Bowechurch,
I have gone to a Bawdy-house.

sp.speaker: Honest.
sp.p: Nay it appears so, that now your Master. hath smelt out your knavery.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
Not to commit in very deed good friend, but only to see
fashions or to recreate and stir up our drowsy appetites.

sp.speaker: Honest.
sp.p:
Well here comes my fellow Quick, and unless you will
content us for staying, you must along to the Counter.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
I hope you think The Labourer is worthy of his hire:
we will stay here at the Tavern, and Quick I will content thee,
to carry a letter to my master, wherein I will make him a restitution
of his 500. li. by repentance, and show him the way that
my frail nature hath run into.

sp.speaker: Honest.
sp.p: Well, we will be paid by the hour.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: It will not be amiss if you buy an hourglass.

div2.stage: Enter D. Nowel, Gresham, sir Tho. Ramsie, Hobson, Lady Ramsie.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
Come Master. D. Nowell, now we have done
Our worst to your good cheer, we would fain be gone:
Only we stay my kinsman's long return,
To pay this hundred pound to sir Thomas Ramsie.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.p:
Then assure you, he will be here presently:
In the mean time, I have drawn you to this walk,
A Gallery, wherein I keep the Pictures
Of many charitable Citizens:
That having fully satisfied your bodies,
You may by them learn to refresh your souls.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p: Are all these Pictures of good Citizens?

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.p:
They are, and I will describe to you some of their births,
How they bestowed their lives, and did so live
The fruits of this life might a better give.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
You shall gain more in showing this to us,
Than you have shown.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Good Master. Dean, I pray you show it us.
This was the Picture of sir Iohn Philpot sometimes Mayor,
This man at one time, at his own charge,
Levied ten thousand soldiers, guarded the Realm
From the incursions of our enemies:
And in the year a thousand three hundred and eighty,
When Thomas of Woodshed's, Thomas Percie with other noble men,
Were sent to aid the Duke of Britannie,
This said Iohn Filpot furnished out four ships
At his own charges and did release the armour
That the poor soldiers had for victuals pawned.
This man did live when Walworth was Lord Mayor
That provident, valiant, and learned Citizen,
That both attached, and killed the traitor Tyler,
For which good service Walworth the Lord Mayor,
This Felpot, and four other Aldermen,
Were knighted in the field.
Thus did he live, and yet before he died
Assured relief for thirteen poor for ever.

sp.speaker: Gres:
sp.p:
By the marry God a worthy Citizen:
On good my Dean.

sp.speaker: Now:
sp.p:
This sir Richard Whitington three times Mayor,
Son to a Knight, and Prentice to a Mercer,
Began the Library of Gray-Friars in London;
And his Executors after him did build
Whittington College, thirteen Alms-houses for poor men,
Repaired Saint. Bartholmewes in Smithfield,
Glazed the Guild-hall, and built Newgate.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Bones'of'me then I have heard lies,
For I have heard he was a scullion,
And raised himself by venture of a Cat.

sp.speaker: Now:
sp.p:
They did the more wrong to the gentleman.
This sir Iohn Allen Mercer and Mayor of London,
A man so grave of life that he was made
A privy Counsellor to King Henri the eight,
He gave this City a rich Collar of gold,
That by the Mayor succeeding should be worn;
Of which sir William Laxton was the first,
And is continued even unto this year,
A number more there are, of whose good deeds
This City flourished.

sp.speaker: Gresh:
sp.p:
And we may be ashamed,
For in their deeds we see our own disgrace,
We that are Citizens are rich as they were.
Behold their charity in every street,
Churches for prayer, Alms-houses for the poor,
Conduits which bring us water: all which good
We do see and are relieved withal,
And yet we live like beasts, spend time and die,
Leaving no good to be remembered by.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Among the Stories of these blessed men,
So many that enrich your Gallery,
There are two women's Pictures: what were they?

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.p:
They are two that have deserved a memory,
Worthy the note of our Posterity:
This Agnes Foster, wife to sir A. Foster,
That freed a Beggar at the grate of Lud-gate,
Was after Mayor of this most famous City,
And builded the South-side of Lud-gate up,
Upon which wall these Verses I have read.
Devout souls that pass this way,
For Master. Foster late Mayor honestly pray,
And Agnes his Wife to God consecrate,
That of pity this house made for Londoners in Lud. gate:
So that for lodging and water here nothing they pay,
As their Keepers shall answer at dreadful Domesday.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
O what a charitable deed was this!
This Aue Gibson who in her husbands life,
Being a Grocer, and a sheriff of London,
Founded a free School at Ratcliffe,
There to instruct three-score poor children,
Built fourteen Alms-houses for fourteen poor
Leaving for Tutors 50. li. a year,
And Quarterly for every one a Noble.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Why should nor I live so, that being dead
My name might have a register with theirs.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
Why should not all of us being wealthy men,
And by Gods blessing only raised, but
Cast in our minds how we might them exceed
In godly works, helping of them that need.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Bones'a'me it is true: why should we live,
To have the poor to curse us being dead?
Heaven grant that I may live, that when I die,
Although my children laugh, the poor may cry.

sp.speaker: Now.
sp.p:
If you will follow the religious path,
That these have beat before you, you shall win heaven,
Even in the mid-day walks you shall not walk the street,
But widows' orisons, Lazars' prayers, Orphans' thanks,
Will fly into your ears, and with a joyful blush,
Make you thank God that you have done for them:
When otherwise they will fill you ears with curses,
Crying we feed on woe, you are our Nurses.
O is it not better that young couples say,
You raised us up, then you were our decay:
And mothers tongues teach their first-born to sing,
Of your good deeds, then by the bad to wring.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
No more Master. D. Nowell, no more,
I think these words should make a man of flint
To mend his life: how say Master Greshams'

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
Fore-god they have starred tears into my eyes,
And Master. D. Nowel! you shall see
The words that you have spoke, have wrought effect in me.

sp.speaker: Ladie.
sp.p:
And from these women I will take a way,
To guide my life for a more blessed stay.

sp.speaker: Now.
sp.p:
Begin then whilst you live, lest being dead,
The good you give in charge be never done,
Make your own hands your executors, your eyes over-seers,
And have this, saying ever in your mind:
Women be forgetful, children be unkind,
Executors be covetous, and take what they find.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: In my time I have seen many of them.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
I will learn then to prevent them whilst I live,
The good I mean to do, these hands shall give.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: The matter you wot of fit is done.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p: Done knave, what is done?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
Is in hucksters handling sir, and here he commend
him unto you.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p: Marry God knave dost tell me Riddles, what is all this?

sp.speaker: Quic.
sp.p:
A thing will speak his own mind to you,
If you please but to open the lip.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
By your leave Gentlemen, I am come to smell out my
master here: Your kins-man Iohn sir, your kins-man Iohn.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p: O he has brought the hundred pound, where is he?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: It appears by this, the matter is of less weight.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
What more paper!
Fellow, what hast thou brought me here, a recantation?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: It may be so for he appears in a white sheet.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Indeed he seems sorry for his bad life.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
Bad life, bad life knave, what means all this?
Master. D. Nowell, pray read it for me,
And I will read that my kins-man Iohn hath sent:
Where is he knave?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Your worship is no wiser than you should be, to keep
any of that cote.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p: Knave thou meanest.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Knave I mean sir, but your kins-man Iohn,
That by this time is well forward on his way.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
Hey-day, what have we here, knavery as quick as Eels?
We will more of this.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: You were best let me help you hold it sir.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p: Why knave, dost think I cannot hold a paper.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Help will do no hurt for if the knavery be as quicke as
an Eel, it may chance to deceive you.
I am a Merchant made by chance,
And lacking coin to venture:
Your hundred poound has gone toward France,
Your Factor is in the Counter.

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p:
No sir, he is yet but in the Tavern at counter gate,
but he shall soon be in if you please.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
Away knave, let me read on.
My father gave me a portion,
You keep away my due:
I have paid myself a part to spend,
Here is a discharge for you.
Precious cole, here is a knave round with me.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.p:
Your Factor Timothy Thin beard writes to you,
Who as it seems is arrested at your suit.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p: How, at my suit!

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.p:
And hear confesseth by using bad company,
He is run behind hand five hundred pound.
And doth entreat you would be good to him.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
How, run behind hand five hundred pound,
And by bad company: Master. Dean of Paul's,
He is a fellow seems so pure of life,
I durst have trusted him with all I had had.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.p: Here is so much under his own hand.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p: Ha, let me see, who set you to arrest him?

sp.speaker: Quick.
sp.p: Why your kins-man Iohn sir, your kins-man Iohn.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
He, ha, infaith I smell the knavery then:
This knave belike mistrusting of my kinsman,
Would come along to see the money given me:
Mad Jack having no trick to put him off,
Arrests him with a Sergeant at my suit,
There went my hundred pound away: this Thin-beard then
Knowing himself to have played the knave with me,
And thinking I had arrested him indeed,
Confesseth all his tricks with yea, and nay:
So here is five hundred pound come, one run away.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Bones'a'me, Master. Gresham, is my man Iohn
Gone away with your hundred pound?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Faith it appears so by the acquittance that I brought.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
No matter Master. Hobson, the charge you trust him with,
I will see he shall discharge, I know he is wild,
Yet I must tell you I will not see him sunk:
And afore-god it hath done my heart more good,
The knave had wit to do so mad a trick,
Than if he had profited me twice so much.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: He ever had the name of mad Jack Gresham.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
Is the more like his Uncle, Sir Thomas Ramsie
When I was young I do remember well,
I was as very a knave as he is now.
Sirrah, bring Thin-beard hither to me, and sir Thomas Ramsie,
Your hundred pound I will see you paid myself:
Ha ha, mad Jack, Gramercy for this slight,
This hundred pounds makes me thy Uncle right.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p:
Aye sure it is in this Lane, I turned on the right hand coming
from the Stocks, nay, though there was master carles, man
carels, and all careless, I will still be honest Iohn, and scorn to take
any man's ware but I will pay them for it: I warrant they think me
an arrant knave, for going away and not paying, and in my conscience
the master cudgeled the men, and the men the master, and
all about me, when as God save me I did it innocently. But sure
this is the Lane, there is the Windmill, there is the Dogs head
in the pot, and here is the Fryer whipping the Nuns arse: it is
here about sure.

div2.stage: Enter in the shop 2. of Hobsons folkes, and opening the shoppe.

sp.p:
Come fellow Crack, have you sorted up those wares?
Marked them with 54. they must be packed up.

I have done it an hour ago: have you sealed up
My masters Letter to his Factor Iohn Gresham?
It is at Deep in France to send him Matches,
For he must use them at Bristow fair.
Aye, and the Post received it two hours since.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p:
Sure it is here about, the kennel was on my right hand,
and I think in my conscience I shall never have the grace of
God and good luck, if I do not pay it: Gods foot, look here,
look here, I know this is the shop by that same stretch-halter,
O my masters, by your leave good fellows.
You are welcome sir, you are welcome.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p:
Indeed that is the common saying about London, if men
bring money with them.
O sir, money customers to us are best welcome.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p:
You say well, so they should be, come turn over your
books, I am come to pay this same ten pound.

And we are ready to receive money: what might we call
your name?

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p:
Why my name is Iohn Good-fellow, I hope I am not ashamed
of my name.

Your Kin are the more beholding to you, fellow Cracke
turn over the Calendar, and look for Iohn Good-fellow.
What comes it to?

sp.speaker: Tawnie.
sp.p: Ten pound.
You will have no more wares with you, will you sir.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p:
Nay prithee not too fast, let us pay for the old before we
talk of any new.

Iohn Good-fellow, fellow Nimble-chaps, here is no such name
in all our book.

I think thou art mop-eyed this morning, give me the book,
Letter I, Letter I, Letter It when had you your ware?

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p: I had it some ten days ago.

Your name is Iohn Good-fellow you say, Letter I, Letter I,
Letter I: You do not come to mock us, do you. Letter I, Letter
I, Letter I. By this hand if I thought you did, I would knock
you about the ears afore we parted fellow Cracke, get me a
Cudgel ready; Letter I, Letter I Letter I: Foot here is no
such name in all our Book. Do you hear fellow are you
drunk this morning, to make us look for moonshine in the
water?

sp.speaker: Taw:
sp.p:
Fut, art not thou drunk this morning, canst not receive
the money that is due to thee? I tell thee I had ten pounds worth
of ware here.

And I tell thee Iohn Goodfellow, here is no such name in our
book, nor no such ware delivered.

sp.speaker: Taw:
sp.p:
Gods precious, there is a jest indeed, so a man may be
sworn-out of himself, had not I ten pounds worth of ware here?
No Goodman goose, that you had not.

sp.speaker: Taw:
sp.p:
Heyday, here is excellent fellows, are able to make their
master's horns grow through his head in a month, they cannot
only carelessly deliver away his ware, but also they will not take
money for it when it comes.

Do you hear Hoyden, and my master were not in the next
room, I would knock you about cares for playing the knave with
us, ere you parted.

sp.speaker: Taw:
sp.p:
By the mass I think your master had more need knock
you about the ears, for playing the Jacks with him, there is your
ten pounds, tell it out with a wanion, and take it for your pains.

Fut, here is a mad slave indeed will give us ten pound
in spite of our teethes.

Fellow Nimble Chaps, alas let the poor fellow alone, it appears
he is besides himself.

sp.speaker: Taw:
sp.p:
By the mass, I think you will sooner make your master
stark mad, if you play thus with everybody.

sp.speaker: Hobs:
sp.p:
Heyday, bones'a'me, here is lazy knaues.
Past eight o'clock, and neither ware sorted,
Nor shop swept.

sp.speaker: Taw:
sp.p:
Good morrow to you sir, have you any more stomach
to receive money, than your men have this morning?

sp.speaker: Hob:
sp.p:
Money is welcome chaffer, welcome good friend,
Welcome good friend.

sp.speaker: Taw:
sp.p: Here is monsieur malapert your man, scorns to receive it.

sp.speaker: Hob:
sp.p:
How knaues, think scorn to receive my money?
Bones'a'me grown proud, proud knaues, proud.

I hope we know sir you do not use to bring up your servants
to receive money unless it be due unto you.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
No bones'a'me knaues, not for a million:
Friend, come to pay me money, for what, for what,
For what come you to pay me money?

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p:
Why Sir, for ware I had some month ago,
Being Pins, Points, and Laces,
Poting sticks for young wives, for young wenches glasses,
Ware of all sorts which I bore at my back
To sell where I come, with what do you lack, what do you lack?
What do you lack?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Bones'a'me a merry knave: what is thy name?

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p:
My name sir is Iohn Good-fellow,
An honest poor Pedlar of Kent.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
And had ten pound in ware of me, a month ago:
Bones give me the books, Iohn Good-fellow of Kent.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p:
O sir, Nomine et natura, by name and nature,
I am as well known for a good-fellow in Kent,
As your City Summer is known for a knave,
Come sir will you be telling,

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Tell me no callings: bones-of-me here is no such matters
Away knave away, thou owest me none, out of my doors.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p:
How, owe you none say you! this is but a trick to try
my honesty now.

sp.speaker: Hob.
Taw.
sp.p:
Gods dickens here is a jest indeed, master mad, men mad,
and all mad, here is a mad household: do you hear Master. Hobson,
I do not greatly care to take your groat, and I care as little to
spend it, yet you shall know I am Iohn, honest Iohn, and I will not
be out faced of my honesty, here I had ten pounds worth of ware,
and I will pay for it.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Nimble-chaps, call for help Nimble-chaps,
Bones'of'me the man begins to rave.

Master I have found out one Iohn Tawnie-cote,
Had ten pounds worth of ware a month ago.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p:
Why that is I, that is I: I was Iohn Tawnie-cote then,
Though I am Iohn Gray-cote now.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Iohn Tawnie-cote! welcome Iohn Tawnie-cote.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p: Foot do you think I will be out faced of my honesty?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
A stool for Iohn Tawnie-cote, sir good Iohn Tawnie-cote.
Honest Iohn Tawnie-cote, welcome Iohn Tawnie-cote.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p:
Nay, I will assure you we are honest all the generation of us,
There it is to a Doit I warrant it, you need not tell it after me,
Foot do you think I will be out-faced of mine honesty?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Thou art honest Iohn, honest Iohn Tawnie-cote:
Having so honestly paid for this,
Sort up his pack straight worth twenty pound,
I will trust thee honest Iohn, Hobson will trust thee:
And any time, the ware that thou dost lack,
Money or money not, I will stuff thy pack.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p: I thank you Master Hobson, and this is the fruit of honesty.

sp.speaker: Pur.
sp.p:
Be your leave Master. Hobson, I bring this favour to you,
My royal Mistress Queen Elizabeth,
Hath sent to borrow a hundred pound of you.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
How, bones a me, Queen know Hobson, Queen know Hobson?
And send but for one hundred pound. Friend come in
Come in friend, shall have two, Queen shall have two:
If Queen know Hobson, once her Hobsons purse,
Must be free for her she is Englands Nurse:
Come in good friend, ha, Queen know Hobson,
Nay come in Iohn we will dine together too.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p:
Make up my pack and I will along from you
Singing merrily on the way,
Points, Points, Gloves, and Purses,
Pokingsticks, and black Jet-rings,
Cambrics, lawns, and pretty things:
Come maids and buy my back doth croak,
I have all that you want: what do you lack?
What do you lack?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
Our City's Sword-bearer and my very good friend,
What have our honourable Court of Aldermen
Determined yet shall Gresham have a place,
To erect this worthy building to his name,
May make the City speak of him for ever.

sp.speaker: Sword.
sp.p: They are in earnest counsel sir about it.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
Be you my Agent to and fro to them,
I know your place and will be thankful to you:
Tell them I wait here in the Mayor's Court,
Beneath in the Sheriff's Court my workmen wait
In number full a hundred, my Frame is ready,
All only stay their pleasure, then out of hand
Up goes my work, a credit to the Land.

sp.speaker: Sword.
sp.p: I shall be dutiful in your request.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
Do good Master. Sword-bearer, now when this work is raised,
It shall be in the pleasure of my life,
To come and meet our Merchants at their hour,
And see them in the great storm that is
Walk dry, and in a work I raised for them:
Or fetch a turn within my upper walk,
Within which square I have ordered Shops shall be
Of neat but necessariest Trades in London.
And in the richest sort being garnished out,
It will do me good to see shops with fair wives
Sit to attend the profit of their husbands:
Young maids brought up young men as prentices.
Some shall prove masters and speak in Greshams praise,
In Greshams work we did our fortunes raise.
For I dare say both Country and the Court,
For wares shall be beholding to this work.

div2.stage: Enter Sword bearer, Lord Mayor, and Sheriffes.

sp.speaker: Sword.
sp.p:
Master. Gresham,
Thus sends the Lord Mayor and Court of Aldermen.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p:
Or rather come to bring the news ourself:
We have determined of a place for you
In Corne-hill, the delightful of this City,
Where you shall raise your Frame: the City at their Charge
Hath bought the houses and the ground,
And paid for both three thousand five hundred three and twenty pound;
Order is given the houses shall be sold,
To any man will buy them and remove them,

sp.speaker: Shirife.
sp.p:
Which is already done, being fourscore households,
Were sold for 478. pound.
The plot is also planed at the City's charges,
And we in name of the whole Citizens,
Do come to give you full possession
Of this our purchase, whereon to build a Burse,
A place for Merchants to assemble in,
At your own charges.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
Master Sheriff I will do it, and what I spend therein,
I scorn to lose day, neglect is a sin:
Where be my work men?

sp.speaker: Work.
sp.p: Here, here with trowel and tools ready at hand.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
Come fellows, come:
We have a Frame made, and we have room
To raise it: but Master. D. Nowell, and Master. Hobson,
We have your presence in a happy time,
This seventh of June we the first stone will lay
Of our new Burse, give us some Bricks:
Here is a brick, here is a fair Sovereign,
Thus I begin, be it hereafter told
I laid the first stone with a piece of gold,
He that loves Gresham follow him in this,
The gold we lay, due to the workmen is.

sp.speaker: Worke.
sp.p: O God bless Master. Gresham, God bless Master. Gresham.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p:
The Mayor of London Master. Gresham follows you:
Unto your first this second I do fit,
And lay this piece of gold a top of it.

sp.speaker: Shri.
sp.p: So do the Sheriffs of London after you.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
And bones of me, old Hobson will be one,
Here is fellows there is my gold give me a stone.

sp.speaker: Work.
sp.p: God forbid a man of your credit should want stones

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.p: Is this the Plot sir of your work in hand?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p: The whole Plot both of form and fashion.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.p:
In sooth it will be a good edifice,
Much Art appears in it: in all my time
I have not seen a work of this neat form:
What is this vaultage for, is fashioned here?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
Stage for Merchants' ware and strangers goods,
As either by exchange or otherways are vendable.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.p:
Here is a middle round and a far space,
The round is greater, and the space
Seems open: your conceit for that?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
The grates give light unto the Cellarage,
Upon the which I will have my friends to walk,
When heaven gives comfortable rain unto the earth:
For that I will have covered.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.p: So it appears.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
This space that hides not heaven from us,
Shall be so still, my reason is,
There is Summers heat, as well as winters cold,
And I allow and here is my reason for it,
It is better to be bleaked by winters breath,
Than to be stifled up with Summers heat:
In cold weather walk dry and thick together,
And every honest man warm one another:
In Summer then when too much heat offends,
Take air in Gods name Merchants or my friends.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.p: And what of this part that is over head?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
Master. Dean in this:
There is more ware there than in all the rest,
Here like a parish for good Citizens
And their fair wives to dwell in, I will have shops
Where every day they shall become themselves
In neat attire, that when our Courtiers
Shall come in trains to pace old Greshams Burse,
They shall have such a girdle of chaste eyes,
And such a globe of beauty round about:
Ladies shall blush to turn their vizards off,
And Courtiers swear they lied when they did scoff.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.p:
Kind Master. Gresham this same work of yours,
Will be a Tomb for you after your death,
A benefit to Tradesmen and a place
Where Merchants meet their traffic to maintain,
Where neither could shall hurt them, heat, nor rain.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
O Master Nowell I did not forget
The troublesome storm we had in Lumbar-steet,
That time Sir Thomas and I were adversaries,
And you and Master. Hobson made us friends.
I then did say, and now I will keep my word,
I saw a want and I would help afford:
Nor is my promise given you when you showed
That rank of charitable men to us,
That I would follow their good actions
Forgot with me, but that before I die,
The world shall see I will leave like memory.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Fore-God my Lord, have you beheld the like!
Look how it streaks, what do you think of it?

sp.speaker: Shir.
sp.p:
It is a strange Comet Master. Hobson,
My time to my remembrance hath not seen
A sight so wonderful. Master. D. Nowell,
To judge of these things your experience
Exceedeth ours, what do you hold of it?
For I have heard that Meteors in the air,
Of lesser form, less wonderful than these,
Rather fore-tell of danger's imminent,
Than flatter us wish future happiness.

sp.speaker: D. Now.
sp.p:
Art may discourse of these things none can judge
Directly of the will of heaven in this,
And by discourse thus far I hold of it.
That this strange star appearing in the North,
And in the constellation of Cassiopey,
Which with three fixed stars commixed to it,
Doth make a Figure Geometry call,
Lozenge-wise called of the learned Rombus,
Conducted with the hourly Moon of heaven,
And never altered from the fixed sphere,
Foretells such alteration that my friends,
Heaven grant with this first sight our sorrow ends.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
God, will be done Master. Dean, hope what hap will,
Death doth not fear the good man but the ill.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
Well said Master Hobson.
Let us have a day, that if death come tomorrow
He is rather messenger of joy than sorrow.
Now sir what news from Barbary?

sp.speaker: Fact.
sp.p: Unwelcome news sir, the King of Barbary is slain.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p: Ha, slain by treason or by war.

sp.speaker: Fact.
sp.p:
By war, in that renowned Battle,
Swift Fame desires to carry through the world:
The Battle of Alcasar, wherein two Kings
Besides this King of Barbary was slain,
Kings of Morocco and of Portugal,
With Stewkeley that renowned Englishman
That had a spirit equal with a King,
Mad fellow with these Kings in war-like strife,
Honoured his Country and concluded life.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
Could news birladie, the venture Gentlemen
Of threescore thousand pound with that dead King,
Lies in a hazard to be won or lost:
In what estate consists the Kingdom now?

sp.speaker: Fact.
sp.p:
In peace, and the succeeding happy,
Was crowned then King when I took ship from thence.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
To that King then be Messenger from us,
And by the sound of Trumpet summon him:
Say that thy Master and a London Merchant,
Craves due performance of such covenants
Confirmed by the late King unto ourself,
That for the sum of three-score thousand pound,
The traffic of his Sugars should be mine.
If he refuse the former bargain made,
Then freely claim our money that we lent:
Say that our coin did stead the former King,
If he be Kind we have as much for him.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
By the Marie-god it was a dangerous day,
Three Kings beside young Stewkeley slain:
I will tell you my Lord Mayor what I have seen
When sword and bucklers were in question,
I have seen that Stewkeley beat a street before him,
He was so familiar grown in every mouth,
That if it happened any fighting were,
The question straight was, was not Stewkely there.
Bones'a'me he would hew it. Now, what news with you?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Here is a Letter sent you from Iohn Gresham.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
O an answer of a Letter that I sent,
To send me Matches against Bristow fair,
If then any were come.

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p:
I cannot tell Sir well what to call it, but in steed of matches
of ware, when you read your Letter, I believe you will find
your Factor hath matched you.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
What is here, what is here.
As near as I could guess at your meaning, I have laboured to furnish
you, and have sent you 2. thousand pounds worth of Match.
How, bones knave, 2. thousand pounds worth of Match!

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
Faith Master. never chafe at it, for if you cannot put it away
for Match, it may be the hang-man will buy some of it for halters.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Bones'a'me, I sent for matches of ware, fellows of
ware.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p:
And Match being a kind of ware, I think your Factor
hath matched you.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
The blazing Star did not appear for nothing:
I sent to be sorted with matches of ware,
And he hath sent me naught, but a commodity of Match,
And in a time when there is no vent for it.
What do you think of it Gentlemen,
I little thought Jack would have served me so.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
Nay Master. Hobson grieve not at Iack's cross,
My doubt is more and that I laugh at less.

sp.speaker: 1. Lord.
sp.p:
You have travelled sir, how do you like this building?
Trust me it is the goodliest thing that I have seen,
England affords none such.

sp.speaker: 2. Lord.
sp.p:
Nor Christendom:
I might say all the world has not his fellow.
I have been in Turkey's great Constantinople,
The Merchants there meet in a goodly temple,
But have no common Burse in Rom, but Rome is
Built after the manner of Franckeford, and Emden:
There where the greatest Marts and meeting places
Of merchants are have streets and pent-houses,
And as I might compare them to themselves,
Like Lumber-street before this Burse was built.

sp.speaker: 1. Lord.
sp.p: I have seen the like in Bristow.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Good morrow to your honours.

sp.speaker: 2. Lord.
sp.p:
Thanks to my good Lord Major.
We are gazing here of Master. Greshams work.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: I think you have not seen a goodlier Frame.

sp.speaker: 2. Lord.
sp.p:
Not in my life, yet I have been in Venice,
In the Realto there called Saint Mark's,
It is but a babble if compared to this.
The nearest that which most resembles this,
Is the great Burse in Anwerpe, yet not comparable
Either in height or wideness: the fair Cellarage,
Or goodly shops above: O my Lord Major,
This Gresham hath much graced your City London,
His fame will long outlive him.

sp.speaker: 1. Lord.
sp.p:
It is reported you sir Thomas Ramsie are as rich as he.
This should incite you to such noble works,
To eternize you.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p:
Your Lordship pleases to be pleasant with me,
I am the meanest of a many men
In this fair City, Master. Greshams fame
Draws me as a spectator amongst others,
To see his cost, but not compare with it.

sp.speaker: 1. Lord.
sp.p: And it is cost indeed.

sp.speaker: 2. Lord.
sp.p:
But when to fit these empty rooms about here,
The pictures graven of all the English Kings
Shall be set over and in order placest,
How glorious will it then be?

sp.speaker: 1. Lord.
sp.p: Admirable!

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: These very Pictures will surmount my wealth.

sp.speaker: 1. Lord.
sp.p: But how will Master. Gresham name this place?

sp.speaker: 2. Lord.
sp.p:
I heard my Lord. of Lecester to the Queen
Highly commend this work, and she then promised
To come in person and here christen it,
It cannot have a better God-mother.
This Gresham is a royal Citizen.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p:
He feasts this day the Russian Ambassador,
I am a bidden Guest:
Where if it please you.

sp.speaker: 1. Lord.
sp.p:
Good sir Thomas,
We know what you would say, We are his Guests
Invited two: yet in our way we took
This wonder worth our pains, it is our way
To Bishop-gate to Master. Greshams house,
Thither so please you we will associate you.

div2.stage: Enter Gresham leading in the Ambassadour, Musick, and a Banquet serued in: the Ambassadour set: Enter Sir Tho. Ramsie, the 2. Lords, my Lady Ramsie the Weights in Sergeants gowns with one Interpreter.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
Lords all at once welcome, welcome at once,
You come to my new buildings up sitting,
It hath been long in labour now deliver.
And up; anon we will have a health to it.
This Russian Prince the Emperor's Ambassador
Doth not our Language understand: Interpreter,
Say that the we bid him welcome.

sp.speaker: Inter.
sp.p:
The Prince speaks Latin,
And in that language we will interpret for him:
Salutem tibi optat et adicentum tuum grauissume iste Londinensis.

p.foreign:
Istum libens audio, agesilli meo nomine Ex
animo gratias, funde quod bibamus.

sp.speaker: Inter.
sp.p:
He gladly thanks you for his royal welcome
And drinks to you.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
We understand that sign.
Come let our full crowned cups overflow with wine,
Welcome again fair Lords.

sp.speaker: 2. Lord.
sp.p:
Thanks Master. Gresham.
We have been viewing of your works.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
My Burse how do you like it Lord,
It is a pretty babble.

sp.speaker: 2. Lo.
sp.p:
It is a fair work.
Her Majesty intends to name the place.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
She doth her servant Gresham too much grace,
It will be pretty when my Pictures come
To fill those empty rooms, if that holds,
That ships rich is worth her weight in gold.

sp.speaker: 1. Lo.
sp.p: It will be rare and famous.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p: What was it that the Russian whispered?

sp.speaker: Inter.
sp.p:
He ask me what interpreter the Queen
Would in his Embassy employ.

sp.speaker: Giesh.
sp.p:
None, tell him none.
For though a woman, she is a rare Linguist,
Where other Princes use Interpreters,
She propria voce, I have some Latin too:
She of herself hears all their Embassies,
And herself answers them without Interpreter,
Both Spanish, Latin, French, and Greek,
Dutch, and Italian, so let him know:
My Lord of Lecester sent me word last night,
And I am prouder of it then on my building,
The Queen to grace me and my works the more,
The several Ambassadors then will hear,
And them in person answer.

sp.speaker: 2. Lord.
sp.p: It is most true.

div2.stage: Enter a Gentleman wispering to sir Thomas Ramsie.

sp.speaker: Gresham.
sp.p:
The Russian with the French.
What would that Gentleman sir Thomas?

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p:
He is a Merchant and a Jeweller:
Amongst other stones he saith he hath a Pearl
Orient and round, weighing so many carets
That it can scarce be valued: the French king,
And many other Dukes have for the riches
And prize refused to buy it: now he comes,
To offer it to this Ambassador.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
Show him the Pearl Interpreter:
The Lord Ambassador.

p.foreign:
Mercator quidem et aurifex spectandum, tibi profert
Gëmam domine serenissime.
Et pulchra et principe digna interroga quanti indicat

sp.speaker: Inter.
sp.p:
He commends it to be both rich and fair,
And desires to know how you value it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: My prise sir, is fifteen hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.p: Quanti valet?

p.foreign: Non, non nimis peceara est ista Gemma,

sp.speaker: Inter.
sp.p: He saith it is too dear, he will not buy it.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p: I will peruse your pearl, is that your prise?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I cannot bate one crown and gain by it.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
We will not be accessory to your Loss,
And yet consider all things some may think us
To be but bare of treasure at this time,
Having disbursed so much about our works:
Yet if our ships and Trade in Barbary
Hold currant we are well: what news from Sea,
How stands my ships?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Your ships in which all the Kings pictures were,
From Brute unto our Queen Elizabeth:
Drawn in white marble, by a storm at sea
Is wrecked and lost.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
The Loss, I way not this:
Only it grieves me that my famous building,
Shall want so rich and fair an ornament.

sp.speaker: L. Ram.
sp.p:
It touches all the City; for those pictures
Had doubly graced this royal edifice.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: Methinks the ships loss most should trouble you.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
My ships but wealth, why we have wealth;
The pictures were the grace of my new Burse,
So I might them in their true foam behold,
I cared not to have lost their weights in gold.

sp.speaker: 1. Lord.
sp.p: A noble Citizen.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
Our Factor, what good news from Barbary?
What says the King, speak, didst thou summon him?
Or hast thou brought my threescore thousand pound?
Or shall I have the Sugars at that rare?
If so, new marble Pictures we will have wrought,
And in a new ship from beyond-sea brought.

sp.speaker: Fact.
sp.p:
The King that in the regal chair succeeds
The King late dead I summoned, and demanded
Either your money tendered, or the Sugars
After the rate proposed, he denied both
Alleging though he was successive heir,
He was not therefore either tide to pay
The late Kings debts, nor yet to stand unto
Unnecessary bargains: notwithstanding
To gratify your love, the King hath sent you
As presents, not as satisfaction:
A costly dagger, and a pair of slippers,
And there is all for you three-score thousand pound.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p: Byrlady a dear bargain.

sp.speaker: 1. Lord.
sp.p:
I fear me this will plague him, a strange cross,
How will he take this news, loss upon loss.

sp.speaker: 2. Lord.
sp.p:
Nay, will it not undo him, doth he not wish
his buildings in his purse.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
A dagger that is well,
A pair of slippers come unto my shoes,
What 30. thousand pound in sterling money,
And paid me all in slips, then Hautboys play,
On slippers I will dance all my care away:
Fit, fit, he had the just length of my foot.
You may report Lords when you come to Court,
You Gresham saw a pair of slippers wear
Cost thirty thousand pound.

sp.speaker: 1, Lo.
sp.p:
Somewhat too dear.
Nor yet for all this treasure we have lost,
Repents it us one penny of our cost.

sp.speaker: 2. Lo.
sp.p: As royal in his virtues as his buildings.

sp.speaker: Ram.
sp.p: These losses would have killed me.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
Jeweller,
Let us see thy pearl: go pound it in a Mortar,
Beat it to powder then return it me,
What Dukes, and Lords, and these Ambassadors
have even before our face refused to purchase
As of too high a price to venture on,
Gresham a London Merchant here will buy.
What is it broken small? fill us some wine,
Fuller, yet fuller till the brim overflows,
Here 16000. pound at one clap goes,
Instead of Sugar, Gresham drinks this pearl
Unto his Queen and Mistress: pledge it Lords,
Who ever saw a Merchant bravelier fraught,
In dearer slippers or a richer draught?

sp.speaker: L. Ram.
sp.p:
You are an honour to all English Merchants
As bountiful as rich, as Charitable
As rich as renowned as any of all.

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
I do not this as prodigal of my wealth,
Rather to show how I esteem that loss
Which cannot be regained, A London Merchant
Thus tread on a kings present: Jeweller,
My Factor shall deliver you your money.
And Lords so please you but to see my School,
Of the seven learned liberal Sciences,
Which I have founded here near Byshops-gate,
I will conduct you. I will make it Lords
An University within itself,
And give it from my revenues maintenance.
We are not like those that are not liberal
Till they be dying, what we mean to give,
We will bestow, and see done whilst we live.
Attendance, come, the ambassador, guess all,
Your welcome is great, albeit your cheer is but small

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p:
Hard world, when men dig living out of stones,
As wretched miserable I am enforced:
And yet there lives more pity in the earth,
Than in the flint-bosoms of her children,
For she is content to have her aged breast
Mangled with mattocks, rent and torn with spades,
To give her children and their children bread,
When man more flinty than her stony Ribs
That was their mother, neither by entreats,
Tears, nor complaints will yield them sustenance,
But it is our ages fault the mightier,
Tear living out of us, we out of her.

div2.stage: Enter Hobson in his gowne and slippers.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Mother a me what a thick mist is here:
I walked abroad to take the mornings air,
And I am out of knowledge, bones'a'me
What Meads, what Enclosures have we here?
How now old Hobson, dote in thine old age?
A fool a threescore, whether wilt thou wit?
I crossed the water in my gown and slippers,
To see my rents and buildings of the Bankside,
And I am slipped clean out of ken, fore-god
A woolgathering.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p:
Either mine ear is deceived,
Or I should know that tongue: it is so indeed,
Each word he speaks makes my torn heart to bleed.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, I smile at my own foolery,
