Now I remember mine old Grandmother
Would talk of Fairies and Hobgoblins,
That would lead milkmaids over hedge and ditch,
Make them milk their Master. neighbour's kine,
And ten to one this Robin Godfellow,
Hath led me up and down the mad man's maze.
I hear some company, for shame all whist,
Sit thee down Hobson a right man, in the mist.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p:
It is he alas, when the rough hand of want
Hath cast us down, it loads us with mishaps:
I broke my day with him, O had that fatal hour
Broken me heart: and Villain that I was,
Never so much as write in my excuse,
And he for that default hath sewed my bill,
And with an execution is come down
To seize my household stuff, imprison me,
And turn my wife and children out of doors,
What shall I fly him? no he is pitiful:
Then with my tears I will importune him:
God save you Master. Hobson.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Hobson, Bones-a-me,
What voice is that? art thou a man, or friend?
Tell me if thou beest that will of the wisp,
That leadest me this wild Morris: I conjure thee
To leave me to myself.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
O Master. Hobson,
As ever you have been a poor man's friend,
Continue still so, Insult not over thy fortunes,

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: I am in the mist, what art thou, speak?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: A Debtor of your worships.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
A Debtor of mine, mother of me thou liest,
I know thee not, nor do I know this place:
If thou owest me anything, pay me with thy love,
And if thou beest acquainted in these woods,
Conduct me to some Town, or direct road
That leads to London, and I will here discharge thee
Of debts and duties, and beside impart
Somewhat to cherish thee.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p:
What should I think?
He knows me, and for fear I should escape him,
He would entice me to the Officers.
O Master Hobson though not for mine own,
Yet for my wife and my poor children's sakes,
If your intent be to imprison me,
Upon my knees I do entreat you spare me:
The goods you trusted me withal, I have not wasted
In riot and excess, but my kind heart,
Seeing my helpless neighbours in distress,
By reason of the long and extreme dearth,
Some I relieved, some trusted with my goods,
Whose poverties not able to repay.
Then bear with me a little, your rich store
Hath saved my life and fed a hundredth more.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Now bones a me another Tawniecote:
What is thy name Knave?

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p: Iohn Rouland sir,

sp.speaker: Hobson.
sp.p:
Bones a me!
I thought as much: art not thou Tawnicote?

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p: I am the man whom you called Tawniecote.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
And I the Hobson that will pity thee:
Now bones a me, what makest thou with a spade?

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p:
This spade alas, it is all the wealth I have,
When my poor wife and children cry for bread,
They still must cry till these have purchased it:
They must go naked till these hardened hands,
When the cold breath of Winter strikes on them,
Till these have earned it.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Now alas good soul,
It melts my heart to hear him, and mine eyes
Could weep for company, what earnest a day?

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p:
Little God knows:
Though I be stirring earlier than the Lark,
And at my labour later than the Lamb,
Towards my wife and children's maintenance,
I scarcely earn me three-pence by the day.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Alas the while, poor soul I pity them,
And in thy words as in a looking-glass,
I see the toil and travel of the country,
And quiet gain of cities' blessedness.
Heaven's will for all, and should not we respect it
We were unworthy life: but bones of me,
Dost thou think to pay me twenty pound,
And keep thy charge, earning a groat a day?

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p:
God bless my labours, I hope I shall,
I have this quarter by exceeding thrift,
Bare clothing, and spare diet scraped together
Five shillings in a purse which I lay up,
Towards your worships debt.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Give it me, somewhat hath some savour,
And yet shall I spend that which the poor labourer got?
No God forbid, old Hobson never will ear,
Rather than surfeit upon poor men's sweat:
Take it again, and buy thy children bread.
But soft the mist doth break, what town is this?

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p: Dedford if it like your worship.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Bones'a'me, to Detford came I to do charity:
I see it was Gods appointment,
But who comes here, bones'a'me honest Tim,
It was said in London you were bound for France,
And I determined to have write by you.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
By yea and nay, Master. Hobson it is no untruth, I was bound
for France, landed in France, dispatched some secret business for a
sister in France, and from her have french tokens to deliver to the
sister hood, whom I shall first encounter in England.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Bones'a'me Tim, so speedy in your journey,
It seems your business was of much import.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
Verily it was, and it stood chiefly between two women:
and as you know women love to have their business dispatched.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Mother a me Tim, I am glad of it,
But how does my factor Iohn Gresham in France?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
You gravely may better consider of that than I can discourse,
but withal I pray you think he is a wild youth: there
are Taverns in France, yet I do not think Iohn Gresham is given
to frequent them, and yet I must remember you, he is a youth,
and youth may be drawn to expenses, England is on this side
France, on it, the Sea betwixt him and his Master, but I do
not think him guilty, yet I could say.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Mother of me, leave off these Parables,
And tell me plainly, is he not a wencher?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p:
By yea, and by nay sir without Parable, I am no telltale,
I have seen him in company with Madonna such a one, or
such a one, it becomes not flesh and blood to reveal: your worship
knows he is in France, the Sea betwixt him and you, and
what a young youth in that case is prone unto: your gravity is
wise, I will not say so much as I saw him drinking with a French
Lady, or Lass in a Tavern, because your gravity is wise, but
if I had, it had been less than perhaps you imagine on such a
wild youth, as he no question does deserve.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Mother of me it is so, in a French, Tavern
Kissing the Lady, and the Sea betwixt us:
I am for you Master. Iohn: thus in my gown and slippers,
And night-cap and gown I will steppe over to France,
Here Tawnicote, receive thou my sealed ring,
Bear it to my Factor, bid him by that token
Sort thee out forty pounds worth of such wares
As thou shalt think most beneficial:
Thou art a free-man, up with thy Trade again,
I will raise thee Rouland, if God say Amen.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p: I know not how.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Tut bones a me man peace,
Hobson will do it; Thou owest me but twenty pound,
I will venture forty more, Timothy here shall be thy witness
To my Factor in this business.
To all our friends in London say, I am gone
Over to France, I am for your Master. Iohn.

sp.speaker: Courtez.
sp.p:
Sweet youth thou art too young, and yet scarce ripe
To taste the sweetness of my mellowed love.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
That is the reason I set thy teeth an edge thus, but thou
knowest I promised to have about with thee at our last parlay, and
I am come to perform my word, name the weapon.

sp.speaker: Curtez.
sp.p: Nothing but kisses, and enticing looks,

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Then ward your lips well, or you will have the first veny.

sp.speaker: Curtz.
sp.p:
I have no ward but this; my tender Sex
have not the manly skill to break a thrust.
O how I dote on thee! I have tried ere now
The sweaty Spaniard, and the carousing Dane,
The foggy Dutch-man, and the fiery French,
The brisk Italian, and indeed what not?
And yet of all and all, the Englishman
Shall go for me: Aye you are the truest Lovers,
The ablest, last night, and the truest men
That breath beneath the Sun.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Why then the Englishman for thy money, God a mercy
little rogue, there is no love lost I will assure thee. I am my Masters
Factor, and thou hast a Commodity that I must needs take
up, and not enter it into his Cash-book neither. Little thinks
my master in England, what ware I deal withal here in France:
but since it is offered me at the best hand, I will venture on it though I
be a looser by the bargain.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p:
I would be private, lest the tell-tale air
Whisper our love, I prithee let us in,
To the inner chamber, I am jealous
Of all eyes but mine own to look upon thee,
I would have none to see thee but myself:
In amorous arms to fold thee but myself:
To associate, talk, discourse or dally with thee:
Clip, grasp hands, or kiss thee but myself.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Who would not be a Merchant venturer, and lay out
for such a fair return; I shall venture the doubling of my years
presently: I think I have met with a better Commodity than
Matches, and my Master cannot say but he hath met with his
match: this it is to have the Land and the Sea betwixt me and my master,
here can I keep my french Revels, and none say so much as
blake is mine eye, prithee little pinkany bestow this Jewel on me.

sp.speaker: Curtez.
sp.p:
This jewel is a Love: ask my life it is thine:
But this an English factor whom you know
Gave me at his departure out of Rhoane,
And I have vowed to keep it for his sake.
Anything but this Jewel.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
But if I could get his Jewel cleanly, and carry it him
over at my return for a token, it were a jest worth laughing at:
but if thou wilt not give me this Jewel, prithee give me this
same chain to wear for thy sake.

sp.speaker: Curtez.
sp.p:
This was another Countrymans of yours,
He made me swear to keep it till his return:
Ask me aught else, it is thine.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Why then this Ring.

sp.speaker: Curtez.
sp.p:
That you of all the favours that I wear
Could find out nothing but this ring? This ring,
A toy not worth the giving: yet I sooner
Would part with life than this, a dying friend
Bequeathed it at his death: But honey Love
What shouldst thou talk of giving, it is a word
Worn out of use, it sounds not well in French:
A man should still say take, take to his Wench.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Then I say take, take this and this, still take heed of me
lest I show you a slippery trick for this, it is the kindest wench in
Christendom, but she will part with nothing:
Shall we have another wooing Room?

sp.speaker: Curtez.
sp.p:
What Room thou pleasest, dear heart I agree,
Where ever I go, there shall be room for thee.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Any then, I may chance to make you wish rather my
room then, my company and you look not the better to it.

div2.stage: They with-draw: Enter at the other ende of the Stage, Hobson in his Gowne and slippers.

sp.speaker: Hobson.
sp.p:
I have slipped over into France, and in my slippers
Given all my friends the slip, to see this Gallant
My man, he that hath matched me: bones'a'me,
The knave is a Prophet, else it could not be.
He is not at his Lodging; yet by an English Factor,
A fellow knows not me, I was directed
Unto this house, I will know what business
The knave hath here.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Who is there? who is at the door?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Damsel good day, is there not a fellow here an Englishman?

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p:
Here is an English-man, but none of your fellow neither: I hope
sir we are not all fellows at football.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Nay bones'a'me Girl, there is no reason we should be
fellows, but prithee my wench is there not one Jack Gresham here?

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p:
No goodman look like a Goose, but there is one Master. Iohn
Gresham an English Gentleman here: and you know no manners,
you would be taught some.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Bones'a'me goodman Master, Master servant,
Old goodman Hobson keeps Gentlemen to his men
Jack turned to Master. Iohn, marry sir reverence,
The french maid taught me manners: well I hope
We shall have a sight of the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: As you use yourself you may, and you may not.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Thou seest this Jewel well becomes mine ear,
This Ring my finger, and this chain mine arm.

sp.speaker: Curtez.
sp.p:
I will be thy Jewel at thy lips I will hang,
And as this Ring thy finger compasseth,
So shall these arms thy waist: these are but toys,
Let me displace them.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Master. Iohn here is a fellow below would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: With me, what is he?

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: A simple Coxcomb, I will call him up to you.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
do my sweet Buffamacke: some Carrier or base knave
that hangs of my liberality: I hope it is not pure Tim, come for
the second part of my benevolence:
Admit him in that he may praise our fate,
And see us in our choicest pomp and state.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Here is the fellow I told you of sir.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Zoones my Master.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Sante amen: Man Iohn, a wenchart Knave, rack and
manger knave: bones'a'me, cannot a snatch and away serve your
turn, but you must lie at rack and manger? Is this the ware
you deal with servant Iohn?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Chapman's ware sir.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Sirrah, Sirrah, the dealing with such war belongs not to
our Trade: bones'a'me knave, a Prentice must not occupy for
himself but for his Master, to any purpose.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
And he cannot occupy for his Master without the
consent of his Mistress.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: Come you are a knave.

sp.speaker: Ioh:
sp.p: Of your own bringing up sir.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p:
Besides, thou canst not keep open shop here, because
thou art a foreigner, by the laws of the Realm.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p:
Not within the liberty: but I hope the suburbs tolerates
any man or woman to occupy for themselves, they may do it in
the City too, and they be naturalised once.

sp.speaker: Hobs:
sp.p:
aye but sirrah, I will have none of my English Prentices
Frenchified; bones'a'me knave, I will have thee deal with no such
broken Commodities.

sp.speaker: Ioh:
sp.p:
Your Worship must have such as the Country yields,
or none at all. But I pray ye sir, what is our trade?

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: What sayst thou knave?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: That your worship is a Haberdasher of all wares.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: Bones'of'me, a Haberdasher of small wares.

sp.speaker: Ioh:
sp.p:
And that the worst trade in all Christendom, and especially
for French women: If they know a man to be a Haberdasher
of small ware, they will have no dealing with him, and therefore
and you will have any good Commodities here, you must
change your copy, you never were a traveller: and therefore you
know not what belongs to it; but you do clean mistake this
Gentlewoman, and you take her for a light wench, weigh her in
equal balance, and you shall find her no such woman, no such
woman I will assure you.

sp.speaker: Hobs:
sp.p: No, what is she then Iohn?

sp.speaker: Ioh:
sp.p:
Fore God sir, I would not have you wrong the Gentlewoman's
repute, for a world. This Metressa deals for herself
and hath many sorts of ware at command, I was now bargaining
with her about a certain Country Commodity, and had
not your coming marred the Match, one had gone through for it.
And further should you wrong the Ladies reputation here in
France, I will assure you they have the law of their sides, but to
confirm your good opinion of her, this is she of whom I took
up your Commodity of Matches; be sorry for your offence, and
excuse you to her for shame master.

sp.speaker: Hobs:
sp.p: Bones'a'me knave I cannot speak a word of French.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p:
Nor she of English, but all is one; upon her Master, and
what you cannot do in words, perform in dumb signs:
What in your slippers come to take me napping!
I will give you what you come for instantly,
And on the sudden make you so aghast,
You will be glad to pardon what is past.

sp.speaker: Hobs:
sp.p:
Madam, I cry you mercy for this wrong
Done to your Ladyship, I did suspect you
For a bad liver, but I see you clear,
For which mistake, I do remain your servant.

sp.speaker: Courtez:
sp.p: Gramercy Monsieur.

sp.speaker: Hobs:
sp.p:
How, would you my gray Mare see? If it like your
Ladyship, I came by water, and neither of Mares back, not
horse back.

sp.speaker: Courtez:
sp.p: No, no point parla Francoi.

sp.speaker: Hobs:
sp.p:
No indeed Lady, my name is not Frauncis, your servant
and Iohn Hobson.

sp.speaker: Courtez:
sp.p: No point?

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p:
No points; yes indeed Lady, I have points at my
hose, though I go untrust.

sp.speaker: Hobs:
sp.p:
I have no points in my parlour indeed, but I have a
hundred pounds worth in my shop.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Tush fear not lads, for he knows none of you,
Do but buff out a little broken French,
And he will never take you to be Englishmen.

sp.speaker: Omnes Fact.
sp.p: We will second the tother, but manage it.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p:
Be patient I beseech you Gentlemen,
Though you be officers, appointed here
To search suspected places, as this is
A most notorious filthy bawdy house,
And carry all old rusty Fornicators
Above the age of fifty unto prison,
Yet know, this is an honest Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p:
A search, and this a bawdy house! why Iohn,
Bones'a'me knave, How comes this to pass?

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p:
How, must you have money of me? I will know wherefore
first, by your leaves.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Nay Master I would it were but a money matter,
A Cage, or whipping-post, or so, it is worse:
What an old man to chide his Prentice hence,
As if he had some private business,
And then himself get close unto his wench;
Nay whipping is all too good, had you found me so,
There had been work enough, there had been news
For England, and a whole twelve months chiding
Of my good uncle.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: How, must I go to prison for doing amiss?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p:
To prison? nay to whipping, I am sorry,
And to my power I will entreat for you: Fie Master, fie.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: Bones'a'me Iohn, is not this a Lady?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p:
No by my troth Master, such as in the Garden-allies,
Joan is as good as this French Lady.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p:
Is not this Gentlewoman a dealer?
And hath she not a good commodity?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: Yes by my faith sir, I confess both.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: Hath she not ware?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: She hath, and at a reasonable reckoning.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: And may not then a chapman deal with her?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p:
Marry may ye sir, and I will send news to your wife of your dealing:
The cause of your coming to France shall be known,
And what second hand commodities you took up
Since your coming, my mistress in England shall know
What utterance you have for your small wares in France:
Pen and ink, I will set it down in black and white,

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: Bones'a'me Iohn, what Iohn? why honest Iohn?

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p:
Hearty commendations - understand - reverend master
Hobson found with a whore in Roans, - place, a common
bawdy house, - must be whipped.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: No more good Iohn.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: You have had none yet, - whipped about the towns.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: Sweet honest Iohn, why bones'a'me knave Iohn.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p:
In witness whereof, all these honest gentlemen eyewitnesses,
have set to their hands, nay my mistress shall know it, that is flat:
are there not Wenches enough in England, but you must walk
over sea in your slippers, and venture (being not shod) to come
into France a wenching, what an old man too! she shall know
what a slippery trick you would have served her in your slippers
in France.

sp.speaker: Hobs:
sp.p:
Nay, bones'a'me Iohn, friends, sweet Iohn all friends;
I do confess thou hast overreached thy master.
Ca me, ca thee, conceal this from my wife,
And I will keep all thy knavery from thine uncle.

sp.speaker: Ioh:
sp.p: Well sir, In hope of amendment, I am content, and yet

sp.speaker: Hobs:
sp.p:
Nay, bones'a'me, I will take you at your word,
Besides I hope these honest Gentlemen
Will save my credit.

sp.speaker: Ioh:
sp.p: I will entreat for you.

sp.speaker: Hobs:
sp.p: It is Logic to me sir, I understand you not.

sp.speaker: Ioh:
sp.p:
Marry sir they say, if you will walk with them to their
lodgings, for my sake they invite you to dinner.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p:
God a mercy Gentlemen, God a mercy Iohn, but
bones'a'me knave, where are their lodgings?

sp.speaker: Ioh:
sp.p: Hard by, for why do you ask?

sp.speaker: Hobs:
sp.p:
I hope they will bring me to no more bawdy houses,
I would not be taken napping again for two and one:
But Gentlemen I will accept of courtesy, and then Iohn
You shall with me to England, we will show France
Our backs. And you will needs deal for yourself,
Afore your time, you shall do it in England.
Will your walk Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Curtes:
sp.p:
Adieu Monsieur, and Gresham farewell too,
No more of French love, no more french loss shall do.

div2.stage: Enter Sir Thomas Ramsey being Maior, Sheriffe, Sword-bearer. &c.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho:
sp.p:
Well said my Masters, see all things be ready,
To give her Majesty such entertain
As may grace London, and become the state
Her highness brings along,
Where is the Queen now?
She comes along the Strand from Somerset house,
Through Temple-bar, down fleet-street, and the cheap,
The North side of the Burse to Bishops gate,
And dines at master Greshams, and appoints
To return on the South side through Corne-hill,
And there when she hath viewed the rooms above,
And walks below, she will give name to the Burse.

sp.speaker: Sheriffe.
sp.p:
The streets are fit, and all the Companies
Placed in their liveries gainst her return.
But my Lord Mayor, shall these ambassadors
This day have audience?

sp.speaker: Sir Thom:
sp.p:
Admittance if not audience was granted,
See therefore Trumpets, and all kinds of Music
Be placed against her royal interview,
The steps with Arras spread where she ascends,
Besides give charge unto the shop-keepers
To make their best shows in the upper rooms,
Because the Queen intends to compass it.

sp.speaker: Sheriff.
sp.p: It is done my Lord.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho:
sp.p:
The Queen hath dined, the Trumpets sound already,
And give note of her coming, bid the Waits
And Hautboys to be ready at an instant.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Lester and Sussex, are those the Ambassadors?

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.p:
They are dread Sovereign, he that foremost stands,
The Emperor is, the second is the French,
The last is the Florentine.

div2.stage: Here the Queene entertaines the Ambassadors, and in their seuerall languages confers with them.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p:
We will receive them.
Sussex and Lester place the ambassadors,
We at our Court of Greenwich will dilate
Further of these designs, where is Gresham?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p: Your humble subject and servant.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p:
Our leisure now serves to survey your Burse,
A goodly frame, a rare proportion.
This City our great Chamber cannot show us
To add unto our fame, a monument
Of greater beauty: Lecester what sayst thou?

sp.speaker: Lecest.
sp.p: That I my Sovereign have not seen the like.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Sussex nor you?

sp.speaker: Suss.
sp.p:
Madam not I: This Greshams work of stone,
Will live to him when I am dead and gone.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p: God bless thy Grace Queen Besse.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Friend, what are you?

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Knowest thou not me Queen? then thou knowest nobody:
Bones'a'me Queen, I am Hobson, and old Hobson
By the Stocks, I am sure you know me.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p:
What is he Lecester, dost thou know this fellow?
Gresham or you?

sp.speaker: Gresh.
sp.p:
May it please your Majesty,
He is a rich substantial Citizen.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
Bones'a'me woman send to borrow money
Of one you do not know, there is a new trick:
Your Grace sent to me by a Pursuivant,
And by a privy Seal to lend your Highness
An hundred pound: I hearing that my Queen
Had need of money, and thinking you had known me,
Would needs upon the bearer, force two hundred:
The Queen should have had three rather than fail,
I by this hand Queen Besse, I am old Hobson
A Haberdasher, and dwelling by the Stocks:
When thou seest money with thy Grace is scant,
For twice five hundred pound thou shalt not want.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Upon my bond.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
No, no my Sovereign,
I will take thine own word without scrip or scroll.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p:
Thanks honest Hobson, as I am true maid,
I will see myself the money back repaid:
Thou without grudging lendest, thy Purse is free,
Honest as plain.

sp.speaker: Suss.
sp.p: A true well meaning man I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Gresh:
sp.p:
Your Majesty promised to give the name
To my new Burse.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Gresham we will. A Herald and a Trumpet.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.p: A Herald and a Trumpet.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p:
Proclaim through every high street of this city,
This place to be no longer called a Burse,
But since the building is stately, fair and strange,
Be it for ever called, the Royal Exchange.
And whilst this voice flies through the city forth-right,
Arise Sir Thomas Gresham now a Knight.
Be our Ambassadors conducted all
Unto their several lodgings: this 23. of January
A thousand, five hundred, and seventy, Elizabeth
Christens this famous work: now to our Court
Of Greenwich; Gresham, thanks for our good cheer:
We to our people, they to us are dear.

sp.speaker: La: Ram:
sp.p: What think you of my Husband master Dean,

sp.speaker: Now:
La. Ram:
sp.p:
It cheer is my heart, now in his deep of sickness,
He is so charitable, and so well addicted
Unto the poor's relief.

sp.speaker: Now:
sp.p:
It joys me too:
Great is the number of the rich in show
About the City, but of the charitable,
There are but few.

sp.speaker: La. Ram.
sp.p:
Amongst these, I hold old Hobson well deserves
To be ranked equal with the bountifullest:
He hath raised many falling, but especially
One master Rowland, one called Tawnicote:
But now an able Citizen late chosen
A Master of the Hospital.

sp.speaker: Now.
sp.p:
I know him well,
A good sufficient man, and since he purchased?
His Freedom in the City God hath blessed
His travail with increase.

sp.speaker: La: Ram:
sp.p:
I have known old Hobson,
Sit with his neighbour Gunter a good man,
In Christs Church morn by morn, to watch poor couples
That come there to be married, and to be
Their common fathers, and give them in the Church,
And some few Angels for a dower to boot,
Besides they two are called the common Gossips
To witness at the Funt for poor men's Children,
Nor they refuse that on their help do call,
And to speak truth, they are bountiful to all.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p:
Good morrow Master Doctor; my good Lady!
Bones'a'me woman, thou lookest sad today,
Thou hast not drunk a cup of sack this morning.

sp.speaker: La: Ram.
sp.p:
We have been dealing of our charity
This morning, to poor soldiers such as want.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p:
Gods blessing of your heart, need must be fed,
Let us that have it give the hungry bread.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p: Where is master Hobson?

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p:
My new elected master of the Hospital,
What hasty news with you?

sp.speaker: Taw.
Hobs.
sp.p: Where? bones'a'me why? speak, why?

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p:
This day, you have pursued the law severely
Against one Timothy, that stole from you
A hundred pound, and he is condemned for it,
And this day he must die.

sp.speaker: Hobs.
sp.p: Bones man, it is not so.

sp.speaker: Taw.
Hobs.
sp.p:
A horse, a horse, cart-horse, malt horse, anything
To save the knaues life, I protest, I swear
This was the first time that I heard the knave
Hath been in any trouble, bones of me,
It was done without my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p: Young Gresham in his name pursued his life.

sp.speaker: Hob.
sp.p:
They are knaues both, a Horse,
A hundred thousand pound cannot make a man:
A hundred shall not hang one by my means:
Men are more worth than money Master. Rouland,
Come help me to a horse, the next I meet,
To save the knave's life gallops through the street.

sp.speaker: Now.
sp.p:
Men are more worth than money, he says true:
It is said by many but maintained by few.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
He is plain and honest, how many great professors
Live in this populous City, that make show
Of greater zeal, yet will not pay so dear
For a transgressors life: but few are found,
To save a man would lose a hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Now.
sp.p: So suddenly returned?

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p:
He rid too fast for me he hath been at buffets
With a poor Collier, and upon his horse,
Is without saddle, bridle, boots or spurs,
Galloped toward Saint Giles.

sp.speaker: Now.
sp.p: They will take him for a mad man.

sp.speaker: Taw.
sp.p:
All is one to him he does not stand on bravery
So he may do men good, good deeds excel:
And though but homely done, may be done well:

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Heaven prosper his intent: now Master. Doctor,
And Master. Rouland, let me crave your companies,
To see my crazy husband, who hath made you
One of his executors, and would use your pains
In these extremes of sickness.

sp.speaker: Now.
sp.p:
I am pleased
I will give him physic for a soul diseased.
You are an early riser, my good Lord,

The blood of Youth that traffics in the court
Must not be sluggish, your kind remembrance.

My very good Lord, we that are stars that weight upon the train
Of such a Cynthia under which we live
Must not be Tardy.

You have said true, we are starters in one hour,
And our attendance is to weight one such a Queen,
Whose virtue all the world: but to leave that
Which every tongue is glad to commune with,
Since Monsieur's first arrival in the land,
The time that he was here, and the time since,
What royalty hath been in Englands Court,
Both princely revelling, and war-like sport.

Such sports do fitly fit our Nation,
That foreign eyes beholding what we are,
May rather seek our peace, than wish our war.

Heaven bless our Sovereign from her foes intent,
The peace we have, is by her government.
Master. Doctor Parry.
Good Morrow Master. Doctor.
You are an early riser sir.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: My Lord, my Lord, my very good Lord.

This Summer morning makes us covetous
To take the profit of the pleasant air.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: It is healthful to be stirring in a Morning.
It hath pleased the Queen to show him many favours.

You say but right, and since his last disgrace,
The cause so great it had surely touched his life,
Had not the Queen been gracious: he seems at Court
A man more gracious in our Sovereigns eye
Than greater subjects.

She hath given him much preferment,
In greatest place graced him with conference:
Asked for him in his absence, and indeed
Made known to us he is one in her regard.
But did you never hear the cause of his disgrace?

He did intend the murther of a Gentleman,
One Master. Hares here of the Inner Temple,
And so far brought his purpose to effect,
That Master. Hare being private in his Chamber,
He watching as he thought fit time, broke in upon him.
But he assaulted so, behaved himself,
That he did guard himself, and attached him.
From whence he was committed unto Newgate,
And at the Sessions by twelve honest men,
Found guilty of Burglary and condemned to die:
And had died, had her Grace not pardoned him.

She is a gracious Princess unto all,
Many she raiseth, wisheth none should fall.

Fie Master. Doctor,
Your face bears not the habit it was wont,
And your discourse is altered, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p:
And if my brow be sad or my face pale,
They do belie my heart, for I am merry.

Men being as you are, so great in grace
With such a royal Princess, have no reason.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: Room Gentlemen for my Lord. high Steward.

div2.stage: Enter the Earle of Lecester, all the Lords flocke after him, & exeunt.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p:
The discontent desire to be alone,
My wishes are made up, for they are gone.
Here are no blabs but this, and this one clock
I will keep from going with a double lock:
Yet it will strike, this day it must be done.
What must be done? what must this engine do?
A deed of treason hath prepared me too.
These too, these too, why they had life by her,
And shall these two kill their deliverer?
The life that makes me rise? these once my sin
Had forfeited, her mercy pardoned me:
I had been eaten up with worms ere this,
Had not her mercy given a life to this:
And yet these hands if I perform my oath,
Must kill that life, that gave a life to both.
I have taken the Sacrament to do it, conferred
With Cardinal Cemo about it, and received
Full absolution from his Holiness,
Been satisfied by many holy fathers,
During my travels both in France and Italy,
The deed is just and meritorious,
And yet I am troubled when I do remember
The excellency of her Majesty,
And I would fain desist, but that I know
How many vows of mine are gone to heaven,
My letters and my promises on earth,
To holy fathers and grave Catholics:
That I would do it for good of Catholics.
Then in the Garden where this day she walks,
Her graces I will cast behind mine eyes,
And by a subject's hand, a Sovereign dies.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p:
Clear the way Gentlemen for the Queen:
Masters Doctor Parry.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p:
O, let me see a difference in this man!
Before this Queen (that I am come to kill)
Showed me the gracious eye of her respect,
And gave me countenance amongst greatest Earls;
This man was forwarder to thrust me forth,
Than now he is humble to accept me in.
If then her Grace hath honoured me so much,
How can this hand give her a treacherous touch?
The Trumpets speak, heaven what shall I do?
Even what hell, and my damned heart shall thrust me to.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p:
Fair day my Lords, you are all Larks this morning,
Up with the Sun, you are stirring early.

sp.speaker: Lecest.
sp.p: We are all subjects to your Sovereign's light.

sp.speaker: Queen.
Lest.
sp.p: The Queen would walk apart, forbear my Lords.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p:
Now, what makes me shake?
Do Angels guard her, or doth heaven partake
Her refuge?

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.p:
In such a Garden may a Sovereign,
Be taught her loving subjects to maintain;
Each Plant unto his nature and his worth,
Having full cherishing, it springeth forth,
Weeds must be weeded out, yet weeded so,
Till they do hurt, let them in Gods name grow.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Now Queen.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Who is there, my kind friend Master. Doctor Parry?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: My most dread Sovereign.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p:
Why do you tremble Master. Doctor? have you any sure to us?
Shake not at us, we do our Subjects love,
Or does thy face show signs of discontent
Through any heavy want oppresseth thee?
Though at our Court of Greenwich thou wert crossed
In suing to be Master of Saint Catherine's,
To do thee good seek out a better place,
She will give thee that, the which hath given thee grace.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I know your love dread Queen: Now.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p:
Master. Doctor, about the talk we had together,
Of English Fugitives that seek my life:
You told me of them I am beholding to you.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I did no more than duty: O happy time!

sp.speaker: Queen:
sp.p:
And will they still persist? do they desire my blood?
That wake when I should sleep to do them good.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p:
O my maker! Parry, Villain, Traitor,
What dost thou with that Dag?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Pardon dread Sovereign.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p:
Pardon thou villain, shows thou art a Traitor,
Treason my Lords, Treason.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.p:
Ha, by the bluest place of heaven, treason and we so near?
A Traitor with a Dag, Gods holy mother.
Lords guard the Queen: are you not frighted Madam?
I will play the Sergeant to arrest the wretch.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p:
Be not so rash good Lecester, he is dead already,
Stuck with remorse of that he was come to do:
Pray let me speak with him. Say Master. Doctor,
Wherein have I deserved an ill of you,
Unless it were an ill in pardoning you.
What have I done toward you to seek my life,
Unless it were in taking you to grace.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Mercy dread Queen.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p:
I thank my God, I have mercy to remit
A greater sin, if you repent for it.

sp.speaker: Lacest.
sp.p:
My Lords what to you mean, take hence that villain,
Let her alone, she will pardon him again.
Good Queen we know you are too merciful,
To deal with Traitors of this monstrous kind.
Away with him to the tower, then to death,
A Traitor's death, shall such a Traitor have,
That seeks his Sovereign's life that did him save.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.p: Good Lecester.

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.p: Good Queen you must be ruled.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Nay sfoote Jack, hold on thy resolution: they say, that
may happen in one hour that happens not again in seven year,
and I should chance to take her in the right vain, and she kindly
bestow herself upon me, why then there is a man made from
nothing, for before God I have spent all and am not worth
anything, and indeed unless this same good old Lady Ramsie take
some pity upon me and take me for better for worse, God knows
in which of the two Counters I shall keep my next Christmas
in, but by this hand if she will accept of me in this miserable
estate that I am in now, for before God, I have neither money
nor credit, as I am an honest man, and that is more I am feared,
than any man will believe of me, I will forswear all women but
her, and will not kiss any of my neighbours wives for a kingdom.
here is the house,I will knock at the door:
what shall I do it in the
Cavalier humour, with whose within there Ho, or in the Puritan
humour, with by your leave good brother: faith in neither,
for in the one I shall be taken for a swaggering knave, and in the
other to be an hypocritical fool: but honest Jack in thine own
honest humour plain dealing is a Jewel, and I have used it so long
I am next door to a beggar.
But Gods precious, what a plague make these here? these 2.
are two of my Creditors, I must stop their mouths, fleet them
from hence, or all the fats in the fire.
Master. Gresham, you are well met.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
I hope Gentlemen you will say so anon. But you are
alone, are you not?
Alone Master. Gresham, why do you ask?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
A man hath reason to ask, being as I am, that never
seeth his Creditors, but is a feared of the Catch-pole. But you are
kind my friends, and I thank you, you will bear with me.
Aye but Master. Gresham, a man may bear till his back break.

sp.speaker: Iohn:
sp.p:
Aye, Porters may; but you, that are substantial honest Citizens,
there is no fear to be made of your breaking, you know
there is no man so low but God can raise him; and though I am
now out at heels, or so as you think, I am in the way of preferment,
and hope to be able to pay every man within this hour.
We should be glad to see it.
But how pray Sir?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
How? why very easily, if I can compass it: The truth is,
though you would little think it, I am a suitor for my Lord. Ramsey.
But I dare swear she is no suitor to you.

div2.stage: Enter Lady Ramsie, and D. Nowel.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Why that is true too; for if she were a Suitor to me, we
should be man and wife straight and you should have your money
within this half hour. But look, look where she comes: as
you are good-men mum, patience and pray for my proceedings:
If I do speed as I am partly persuaded, you shall have your own
with the advantage, if I should be crossed you know the worst, forbearance
is no acquittance: but mum, if it prove a match and any
of you should chance to be in the Counter, you know my marriage
being spread, my word will be currant, then mum.

sp.speaker: Now.
sp.p: Madam you are welcome into Lumber-street.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I thank your courtesy, good Master. Dean.

sp.speaker: Ioh:
sp.p:
See how fortunately all things chance, if it happen as I
hope it will, she taking a liking to me, here is a Priest to marry us
presently Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady:
sp.p: Would you any business with me sir?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Faith Lady necessary business, and not to go far about the
bush, I am come to be a Suitor unto you, and you know the fashion
of young men when they come a-wooing to ancient widows, the
way to speed is to begin thus.

sp.speaker: La:
sp.p: You are very forward sir.

sp.speaker: Ioh:
sp.p:
You would say so Lady if you knew how forward I would
be: but Madam you are rich, and by my Troth I am very poor,
and I have been as a man should say stark naught: but he goes
fair that never turns, and if now I have a desire to mend and being
in so good a way, you know how uncharitable it were in you
to put me out of it, you may make an honest man of me, if
it, please you and when thou hast made me one, by my Troth
Mall I will keep myself, for I am a Gentle man both by the fathers
side and mothers side, and though I have not the muck of
the world I have a great deal of good Love, and I prithee accept
of it.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Master Dean.
Do you know this Gentleman's business to me.

sp.speaker: Now.
sp.p: Not I, believe me Madam.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
I shall have her sure: why I will tell you Sir, my Lady here
is a comely, ancient, rich widow, and I am a honest, proper, poor
young man, remembering still I am a Gentleman, now what good
her riches may do to her poverty, your gravity may guess: save
a soul perhaps Master. Dean, look you sir, it is but giving my
hand into hers, and hers into mine: Master. Dean, I protest before
God she hath my heart already, and with some three or four
words which I know you have by rote, make us two my Lady
and I, one till death us depart.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
This Gentleman thinks that to be a matter of nothing.
But do you love me as you do protest?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Love you Madam love you by this hand: I shall have
her sure, friends you see how the business goes forward, bring
me your bills tomorrow morning or upon the hope that I have,
you may leave them with me, I shall be able to discharge; Ha,
ha, Jack.

sp.speaker: Ladie.
sp.p:
How will you maintain me Sir, if I should marry
you?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Maintain, what needst thou ask that question?
Foot thou hast maintenance enough for thee and I rod.
If I should marry you. Friends, you see how it goes now, tomorrow
within an hour after I am married, I must take the upper
hand of my Uncle, and the next Sunday I that was scarce worthy
to fit in the Belfry, the Church-wardens fetch me, and seat me
in the Chancel.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Master Dean, I protest, I protest, never since I was widow,
Never did man make so much love to me.
Sir for your love, I am much beholding to you.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p:
Do Mall, prithee do not think it so, be chosen one of
the common Counsel, or one of the Masters of the Hospital,
so perhaps I shall never become it, marry if I should be chosen
one of the Masters of Bridewell, for some of my old acquaintance;
fut, I would take it upon me, vice must be corrected, vice
must be corrected.

sp.speaker: La: Ram:
sp.p:
Fill me a large cup full of Hippocrist,
And bring me hither 20.li. in gold.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
And one of your husbands Livery Gowns, so now
you trouble yourself so much, that gold is to contract us withal:
a simple morning: Friends, you cannot beat me down with
your bills. Master. Dean of Paul's I pray you stay and dine with me
you shall not say me nay, the oftener you come, the more welcome.

sp.speaker: Now.
sp.p: You are merry sir.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
I thank God, and all the world may see I have no other cause,
That I am likely to be so well bestowed.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Sir, you shall not say the love you showed to me,
Was entertained but with kind courtesy:
This for your love, unto your health I drink.
Pledge me.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: I by my Troth Mall will I, wear it as deep as a well.

sp.speaker: Ladie.
sp.p:
Now for your pains there is twenty pound in gold.
Nay, take the Cup too sir, thanks for your love:
And were my thoughts bent unto marriage,
I rather would with you that seem thus wild,
Than one that hath worse thoughts and seems more mild.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Foot will you not have me then?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Yes, when I mean to marry anyone,
And that not whilst I live,

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
See how a man may be deceived. I thought I should
have been suit by this time well, though I shall not have you,
I shall have this with a good will.

sp.speaker: Ladie.
sp.p:
Withal my heart, and for the Love you have shown,
Wish it to thrive with you even as mine own.
tomorrow shall we attend your worship.
Sir here is my bill, it comes to twenty pound.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Friends, Ploydens Proverb. The Case is altered: and by
my troth I have learned you a Lesson, Forbearance is no Acquittance.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What men are these?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
Faith Madam, men that have my hand, though not for
my honesty, yet for the money that I owe them.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What doth he owe you?
Fifty pound, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What you?
A hundred Marks.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
I will pay you both: and sir to do you good,
To all your Creditors I will do the like.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p:
That is said like a kind wench,
And though we never meet again,
We will have one Buss more at parting:
And now I faith I have all my wild oats sown,
And if I can grow rich by the help of this,
I will say I rose by Lady Ramsies kiss.

div2.stage: Enter Queene, Hunsdon, Lecester, Drum, Colours, and Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.p:
A stand there Lords, Whence comes this sound of
shot?

sp.speaker: Lest.
sp.p:
Please it your Majesty, it is thought the Fleet
Lately discovered by your Subject Flemming,
Riding along the Coasts of France and Dunkerke,
Is met and fought with by your Admiral.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p:
Heaven prosper his proceedings; hark my Lords,
Still it increaseth: O had God and Nature,
Given us proportion man-like to our mind,
We would not stand here fenced in a wall of Arms,
But have been present in these Sea alarms.

sp.speaker: Huns.
sp.p:
Your royal resolution, hath created
New spirits in your soldiers' breasts, and made
Of one man three.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Make way there, what is the news,

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p:
Your Royal Fleet bids battle to the Spaniards,
Whose number with the advantage of the wind,
Gives them great odds but the undaunted worth,
And well known valour of your Admiral,
Sir Francis Drake, and Martin Furbisher
Gives us assured hope of victory.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: Where did the royal Navies first encounter?

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p:
From Dover Cliffs we might discern them join,
But such a cloud of smoke environed them,
We could discover naught of their proceedings:
For the great Spanish Fleet had wind and Tide,
God and good hearts stand on your Graces side.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p:
There is for thy news: he that first lent me breath,
Stand in the right of wronged Elizabeth.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: God and his Angels, for Elizabeth.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p:
Welcome in Gods name, what is the news my friend,
Alas, good man: his looks speaks for his tongue.
How stands the sea-fight.

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p:
Much contrarious.
The Spanish Fleet cast in a warlike Rank
Like a half Moon, or to a full bent bow,
Wait for advantage: when amongst the rest
Sir Martin Furbisher blinded with smoke,
And fired in heart with emulating honour,
Gave the proud Spaniard a broad side of shot:
But being within the compass of their danger,
The distant corners of the grippled Fleet
Circled him round: this valiant Furbisher,
With all his brave and gallant followers,
Are folded in death's arms.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p:
If he Survive,
He shall be nobly ransomed: If he die,
He lives an honour to his Nation,
How fares our Admiral?

sp.speaker: Post.
sp.p:
Bravely he sights,
Directs with judgment and with heedful care,
Offends the Foe: England never bred
Men that at sea fight better managed.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p:
It cheers my blood and if my God be pleased
For some neglected duty in ourself,
To punish us with loss of them at sea,
His will be done: yet will we pray for them.
If they return, ourself: will be the first
Will bid them welcome; what says valiant Lecester?
Thou wilt not leave me wilt thou dost thou look pale?
What says old Hunsdon? nay I will speak thy part,
Thy hand old Lord, I am sure I have thy heart.

sp.speaker: Huns.
sp.p: Both hand and heart.

div2.stage: A noyce within crying a Furbisher. Enter a Captaine.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p:
Then let both heart and hand,
Be bravely used in honour of our Land.
Before thou speakest take that if he be dead,
A Queen will see his Funeral honoured.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p:
When the foes ships
Had grasped his ships within a steely girdle,
The valiant Captain overcharged with her,
Having no room for cowardice or fear,
Gave all his ordinance a gallant charge,
Cheered up his soldiers, manned up his fights,
And standing bare-head, bravely on the deck,
When dangerous shot as thick as April hail
Dropped by his ears, he waved his war-like sword,
And with a bold defiance to the foe.
The watch-word given, his Ordinance let fly
With such a fury, that it broke their ranks,
Shottered their sides and made their war-like ships
Like drunkards reel, and tumble side to side:
But to conclude such was the will of heaven,
The true spirit of that Gentle-man,
That being thought hopeless to be preserved,
Yet in wars despite and all the Spaniards scoff,
He brought his ship and soldiers bravely off.

div2.stage: They march one way out, at the other doore enter Sir Francis Drake with Colours, and Ensignes taken from the Spaniards.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p:
War's spite indeed, and we to do him right,
The ship he sailed in, fought in, called War's spite.
Now noble soldiers rouse your hearts like me,
To noble resolution: if any here
There be that love us not, or harbour fear;
We give him liberty to leave our Camp
Without displeasure.
Our Armies royal so be equal our hearts,
For with the meanest here I will spend my blood,
And so to lose it count my only good.
A March, lead on: we will meet the worst can fall,
A maiden Queen will be your General.
What mean these Spanish Ensigns in the hands
Of English Subjects?

sp.speaker: Drake.
sp.p:
Honourable Queen,
They show that Spaniards lives are in the hands
Of Englands Sovereign.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.p:
Englands God be praised
But prithee Drake, for well I known thy name,
And I will not be unmindful of thy worth:
Briefly rehearse the danger of the battle,
Till Furbisher was rescued we have heard.

sp.speaker: Drake.
sp.p:
The danger after that was worse than then:
Valour a both sides strove to rise with honour,
As is a pair of Balance once made even,
So stood the day, inclined to neither side:
Sometimes we yielded, but like a Ram
That makes returnment to redouble strength,
Then forced them yield when our Lord Admiral
Following the chase: Pedro their Admiral,
With many Knights and Captains of account,
Were by his noble deeds taken prisoners,
And under his Conduct are safely kept:
And are by this time landed at Saint Margaret's:
From whence they mean to march along by land,
And at Saint James he will greet your Majesty.
These Spanish Ensigns tokens of our Conquest,
Our Captains took from off their battered ships:
Such as stood out we sunk, such as submitted,
Tasted our English mercy, and survive
Vassals and prisoners to your Sovereignty.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.p:
Next under God, your valours have the praise:
Dismiss our Camp, and tread a royal March
Towards Saint James, where in martial order
We will meet and parley our Lord Admiral,
And set a ransom of his Prisoners.
As for those Ensigns see them safely kept,
And give commandment to the Dean of Paul's,
He not forget in his next learned Sermon,
To celebrate this conquest at Paul's Cross:
And to the Audience in our name declare.
Our thanks to heaven in universal Prayer:
For though our enemies be overthrown.
It is by the hand of heaven, and not our own.
On: Sound a call; Now loving Countrymen,
Subjects, and fellow-soldiers, that have left
Your weeping wives, your goods and children,
And laid your lives upon the edge of death.
For good of England, and Elizabeth,
We thank you all; those that for us would bleed,
Shall find us kind to them and to their seed.
We here dismiss you and dismiss our Camp.
Again we thank you: pleaseth God we live,
A greater recompense than thanks we will give.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Our lives, and livings for Elizabeth.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p:
Thanks; general thanks.
Towards London march we to a peaceful throne,
We wish no wars, yet we must guard our own.
